I was honoured to speak at Burnley's May Day Rally today.  We celebrated the collective achievements of workers and are standing up against Tory attacks on workers rights.

It has become increasingly clear that David Cameron and his Tory government cannot be trusted. They can’t be trusted to make sure the richest pay their fair share of tax. They can’t be trusted to stand up for the local services we rely on. And they can’t be trusted to meet their targets and fix the economy. Send a message to the Tories and vote Labour this Thursday. If you’re with us  share our new advert →

Be the first to watch our Party Election Broadcast.   David Cameron and the Conservatives cannot be trusted. They’ve failed to make sure the richest pay their fair share of tax. They are attacking our public services. And  they have failed to meet their own economic targets.   So stand up this Thursday and send a message to the Conservatives - vote Labour.

At today’s march I made my position  the Labour Party’s position and the labour movement’s position very clear – we stand absolutely against anti-semitism in any form.  As I announced on Friday evening  I am now proposing to Labour’s National Executive Committee that it adopts a code of conduct on anti-semitism and other forms of racism  and I am establishing an inquiry into tackling anti-semitism and other forms of racism under the former director of Liberty Shami Chakrabarti.  As a Labour Party and labour movement we stand absolutely against racism in any form.

Our May Day marches were born out of the demand for an 8 hour day. The chant of those workers in Chicago 130 years ago was  "Eight-hour day  with no cut in pay." I was proud to join and speak at one of the thousands of marches that took place across the world today.  Workers continue to organise together through trade unions to demand the working conditions and rights they deserve.  Earlier this week I was proud to stand with junior doctors. They are campaigning against the imposition of a contract by Jeremy Hunt and here you can watch a little of my speech.

Labour is an anti-racist party to its core and has a long and proud history of standing against racism  including anti-semitism. I have campaigned against racism all my life and the Jewish community has been at the heart of the Labour Party and progressive politics in Britain for more than a hundred years.   We have taken decisive action over allegations of anti-semitism since I became leader  suspending all those involved from membership  and have set up an inquiry under Baroness Royall into reports of anti-semitism in the Oxford University Labour club and elsewhere.  I am now proposing to Labour’s National Executive Committee that it adopts a code of conduct on anti-semitism and other forms of racism  and establishing an inquiry into tackling anti-semitism and other forms of racism under the former director of Liberty Shami Chakrabarti.  There is no place for anti-semitism or any form of racism in the Labour Party  or anywhere in society  and we will make sure that our party is a welcoming home to members of all communities.
The best part of my job is meeting and listening to people across our country.   Yesterday The Guardian came on my trip to Grimsby and Hull.

David Cameron's mental health adviser  Natasha Devon  has admitted there is child mental health crisis.  So why are the Tories cutting funding for child mental health services?   NHS spending on children's mental health services has been slashed by £50 million since David Cameron became Prime Minister.  Tory failure means child mental health services are in crisis with the children most in need abandoned. As Luciana Berger  Labour's Shadow Mental Health Minister  said  "These figures prove the government has broken its promise on mental health."

I would like to make it very clear that we do not tolerate anti-Semitism in any form within the Labour Party.  Today Ken Livingstone was suspended from the Labour Party because of comments he made in an interview this morning and yesterday Naz Shah was suspended for comments she made on social media before she became an MP. Both will be investigated by the Labour Party  as is our procedure in all such cases.  The Labour Party has a zero tolerance approach to all instances of racism  including anti-Semitism. If there are any allegations of anti-Semitism or other instances of racism within the Labour Party  we will take action to ensure they are thoroughly investigated and appropriate action is taken.

257 years ago today one of the great pioneers of women’s equality was born  Mary Wollstonecraft.   In response to Thomas Paine's The Rights of Man  Mary wrote A Vindication of the Rights of Woman  in which she explained - then a radical notion - that women were not inferior to men and education was the key to their emancipation.  It was this belief which led her to setting up a school in Newington Green and that is why I have long supported the campaign for a statue of her to be erected there.

Andy Burnham has campaigned tirelessly for justice for the victims of the Hillsborough tragedy. His statement today on the Inquest was deeply moving and you must watch it to the end to see the reaction.   The Labour Party is very proud to have an MP like Andy.

At Prime Minister’s Questions today  I asked David Cameron why he and his government refuse to listen to those who have dedicated their lives to public service.   Whether it is the teachers who are saying they do not want forced academisation or the junior doctors who say Jeremy Hunt’s plans are not safe for patients and not sustainable for the NHS.    Our teachers should be at the heart of decisions about our education system and our doctors should be at the heart of decisions about our National Health Service.

Today is the second day of the junior doctors' strike. Yesterday  I was proud to join their demonstration.  The NHS is our country's greatest creation. But  it is being failed by Tory policies and a Health Secretary who is not willing to listen to junior doctors.  This strike could have been avoided if Jeremy Hunt had negotiated with doctors  but instead he's opted to impose a contract upon them which is not safe for patients and is not sustainable for our NHS.

I am proud to have joined thousands upon thousands of junior doctors at their demonstration this evening. The NHS is our greatest creation and these doctors are defending it.   Jeremy Hunt  the Tory Health Secretary  has refused to listen and negotiate with the junior doctors - he could have avoided today's action.     It is a decision junior doctors have found agonising to make. Every doctor I’ve asked  "why are you striking?"  says it is because Jeremy Hunt's new contract is not safe for patients and is not sustainable for the NHS.   The contract proposed by the Conservative government does not recognise junior doctors' work on Saturdays as unsociable and does not provide the support staff that will be needed under their plans. Junior doctors are already overworked and the NHS already operates 24 hours a day  7 days per week with junior doctors at its heart.   And let’s not be misled by the term “junior doctors”. They are junior in name only  not by status. They make life-and-death decisions  perform surgery and they are often in charge of whole teams. This contract affects all those doctors on the long pathway to GP or consultant roles. They are trained professionals who account for a third of our medical workforce.    So there is nothing “junior” about them. They are the lifeblood of our NHS; they have a wealth of experience and education that is an asset to our country. That is why today and when the strike continues tomorrow because no doubt Jeremy Hunt will continue to refuse to negotiate; I am with the junior doctors.

Today  after 27 long years  the 96 victims of the Hillsborough tragedy - and their families - have finally received justice.   The youngest victim was just 10  Jon-Paul Gilhooley  and the oldest was 67 years old  Gerard Bernard Patrick Baron. These were fans that went to a football match  as so many of us do  on the 15th April 1989  but never returned to their loved ones.    I pay tribute to the families and friends of all the victims of the tragedy – as well as many others from the city of Liverpool - for the passionate and dignified campaign they have fought for almost three decades. Today they received total vindication for their fight for the truth and for justice.   In the immediate aftermath of the Hillsborough disaster there were some who painted those that died and the fans of Liverpool FC as drunken yobs and thieves. The findings of this inquest clearly show that to have been a lie - fan behaviour didn't cause or contribute to the disaster and the fans have been exonerated of any blame.   All those that attended the semi-final 27 years ago were innocent victims and it is time that those who peddled those vile and malicious lies recognise the deep hurt they have inflicted on tens of thousands of innocent people - and are held to account.

Today junior doctors go on strike for the third time. This time it’s an all-out strike. Jeremy Hunt  the Health Secretary  has refused to listen and negotiate with the doctors - which has left them with no choice but to take this unprecedented action to protect standards and patient safety.  It is a decision junior doctors have found agonising to make. Every doctor I’ve asked  "why are you striking?"  tells me that it is because Jeremy Hunt's new contract is not safe for patients and is not sustainable for the National Health Service.  The message is clear - they are proud of the NHS and want to protect it for future generations. That is why today and tomorrow  I am with the junior doctors.

Heidi Alexander just asked Jeremy Hunt  the Health Secretary  why he rejected a cross-party proposal that could have averted tomorrow’s junior doctors' strike.   The junior doctors' strike is the result of Tory policies that have failed the NHS and Jeremy Hunt’s refusal to negotiate.   Junior doctors are the lifeblood of our NHS. It is this Conservative government that is a threat to patient care and the NHS – not our dedicated junior doctors.

There's an important vote for Co-operative members and I'm supporting a YES vote for motion 12.   Co-operatives have always shaped and challenged the world in which we live. Join me in voting to keep the partnership between the Co-operative Party and the Co-operative Group.  Find out more at http://www.keepit.coop/

There’s an important vote in Parliament tomorrow and we need your help.  The Labour Party wants us to take in 3 000 unaccompanied child refugees from camps in Europe  but David Cameron is refusing to do this. He says he’ll only take in child refugees from camps outside of Europe and over a four year period.  This is simply inadequate. 26 000 unaccompanied children entered Europe last year alone and 10 000 children have gone missing  according to Europol. Cameron’s plan leaves children across our continent in appalling conditions  as I witnessed in the Calais and Dunkirk refugee camps in January  where they are at risk of trafficking and prostitution.  Keir Starmer MP is working to ensure the “Dubs Amendment” to the Immigration Bill is passed.  Labour MPs will be voting for this amendment  but please write to other MPs to ask them to vote for it →

Today I met the US President Barack Obama. We discussed the power of global corporations  the impact of globalisation on working people and the need to take action to reduce inequality across the world.

The National Health Service is Labour's proudest creation  but it is under threat from the Tory Government.  Conservative cuts and policies are failing our hospitals  they are failing patients  and they are failing NHS staff.  We need Labour Councillors and Labour Mayors elected on 5 May who will defend our NHS.   Share if you're with us →

I would like to send my warmest wishes to Jewish communities all over Britain who are preparing for the Pesach holiday.  I have always been moved by the Passover story of the Israelite escape from enslavement. It is a universal message of the struggle for liberation and freedom  and one that continues to inspire many who fight for justice and equality all over the world.   The 19th century Rabbi of the North London Synagogue  Joseph Morris  summed up its meaning when he said: “Passover affirms the great truth that liberty is the inalienable right of every human being."   That is the message I will be thinking of over the Pesach holiday. I believe it is an aim and a principle that every one of us can support and cherish.   I would like to wish you all Chag Sameach.

Last Saturday Ecuador was hit by a devastating earthquake on its  northwestern coast. In the catastrophic aftermath 600 people lost their lives  over 5 000 were injured and about 20 000 people have been made homeless.   Here in the UK  Ecuadorian students  with the support of the Ecuadorian Embassy  have come together to raise funds for their country.   The people of Ecuador would appreciate anything you can spare to support the humanitarian effort there.
On behalf of the Labour Party I wished the Queen a happy 90th birthday. Here's the last part of my speech...

At Prime Minister's Questions today  I asked David Cameron about his forced academisation plans.   This is top-down re-organisation which will cost £1.3 billion - at a time when the education budget is facing the biggest cut since the 1970s - that parents  teachers and governors do not want.

If you just missed it on TV  here is Labour's new Party Election Broadcast. Vote Labour on 5th May: we need Labour Councillors and Labour Mayors - to stand up and defend our public services.  David Cameron's government cares more about large corporations and the richest. He's cut their taxes and is standing by as overseas tax havens rip us off. These are taxes that could pay for the services that most of us depend on.  Labour will stand up for you. Labour will invest in a strong and fair economy that works for all - and put an end to the failed economic policies that threaten our living standards.

The National Health Service is Labour's proudest creation but Conservative cuts and policies are failing patients and failing the NHS. The quality of care patients are receiving is threatened by longer waiting times  service closures and over-worked staff.  This doesn't have to be the case. It is the choices made by the Conservative Party that is pushing the NHS to breaking point. Labour will stand up for the NHS; we will ensure it has the investment it needs.   That's why we're asking you to vote Labour on 5th May - to elect Labour Councillors and Labour Mayors who will defend our NHS.

Statistics from the Department for Education show that 23% of state primary schools are now full or over capacity.   On the day that parents will find out if their child has a place at their school of choice  it is increasingly clear that the Government has no answer to the crisis in school places they have created.  The same figures suggest that 87 primary schools in England now have more than 800 pupils – up from just 16 five years ago – and the number of infants in class sizes of over 30 pupils is also at its highest rate for 15 years.  Labour's shadow Education Secretary Lucy Powell said  "The Tories’ new forced academisation policy will make the school places system implode  as councils lose completely the levers they have to ensure there are enough school places for children."

The Conservatives are trying to force the academisation of all our schools. This is a top down re-organisation  costing over £1 billion - without a shred of evidence that academies improve standards.  At a time when the education budget is being cut for the first time in twenty years  Labour wants money spent on driving up standards.  Labour is campaigning to stop forced academisation and for investment in education. So  if you believe education matters  if you believe all our children matter  if you believe that every child has a right to go to a local school and do their best and succeed - join us  Labour  in opposing forced academisation.

Tens of thousands of people have taken to the streets in London today for the People's Assembly March for Health  Homes  Jobs and Education.  I couldn't join them as I'm campaigning in Liverpool for Labour victories in the local elections on Thursday 5 May.  But  I sent this video to the demonstration and I'm taking the same message around the country - austerity is a political choice  not an economic necessity.  The Labour Party is now an anti-austerity Party and we're standing up against the failed policies of the Tory government.

Today's report from the Trussell Trust shows a 2 612% increase in the number of people who needed food aid to put a meal on the table since David Cameron became Prime Minister.  Kerry McCarthy explains  "the report from the Trussell Trust on food bank usage shows well over 1.1million three day emergency food parcels were provided to people in crisis by the charity's network in 2015-16  compared to 41 000 parcels in 2009-10. ... Food banks have become a truly shameful symbol of a Tory Government that is failing to stand up for ordinary people."

The Conservatives are trying to force the academisation of all our schools. This is a top down re-organisation  costing over £1 billion - without a shred of evidence that academies improve standards - that teachers  governors and parents do not want.  At a time when the education budget is being cut for the first time in twenty years  Labour wants money spent on driving up standards.   This weekend  Labour will be campaigning to stop forced academisation and for investment in education. So  if you believe education matters  if you believe all our children matter  if you believe that every child has a right to go to a local school and do their best and succeed - join us  Labour  in opposing forced academisation.

“I appeal to everyone  especially young people – who will live longest with the consequences – to make sure you are registered to vote. And vote to keep Britain in Europe this June. This is about your future.  “By working together across our continent we can develop our economies  protect social and human rights  tackle climate change and clamp down on tax dodgers.  “You cannot build a better world unless you engage with the world  build allies and deliver change. The EU has proved itself to be a crucial international framework to do that.”  Today Jeremy Corbyn made a passionate speech about the need for us to remain in - and reform - the EU. While the Tories block action to protect our steel industry and tackle tax evasion at an EU level  a Labour government would stand up with allies across the continent to back public enterprise and services  to protect and extend workers’ rights  and to make both Britain and Europe work better for working people.  But we can’t do it without you. If you’re standing with us on 23 June  share this →
I'm live  speaking about why I'm campaigning for Britain to remain in Europe. Please tune in and share.

Waheguru Ji Ka Khalsa; Waheguru Ji Ki Fateh.  I’d like to wish a Happy Vaisakhi to Sikhs celebrating across the UK. This is an opportunity to recognise the huge contribution of the Sikh community and the principles of Sikhism - which we can all learn from.

Waheguru Ji Ka Khalsa; Waheguru Ji Ki Fateh  Happy Vaisakhi to all.  I know this is a very important and special time for Sikhs in the UK  India and across the world.   Vaisakhi marks the birth of the Khalsa and Sikhs are celebrating across the UK in Gurdwaras  homes and in processions in lots of our towns and cities.  We can learn much from the Sikh way of life. Gurdwaras are impressive places of worship in the way that they serve free food to everyone  be they a worshipper or just somebody in need of a hot meal. I'm particularly taken by the story of Emperor Akbar who  in 1569  was told by the 3rd Sikh Guru to sit and share a meal with the poor and the penniless before meeting the Guru. The concepts of social justice and true equality - gender  race  religion  ethnicity - of respect for each other  of treating everyone the same  regardless of where you were born or what background you are from  are concepts shared by the Labour Party.  The Gurus fought against social inequality  fought against injustice  and helped the most vulnerable in society to live their lives with dignity and pride. The creation of the Khalsa by the tenth Sikh Guru  in a ceremony underpinned by personal sacrifice  gave Sikhs a visible identity that ensured they would stand out and that they wouldn’t walk by when they saw injustice or somebody in need.  These are values that we in the Labour Party also share.   The Labour Party wants to build a fairer society where all have the same opportunities in life. We want a Britain which works for all of us  not just the few  a vision of the future with fairness and shared prosperity at its heart and we look forward to working with you.  At this time  we also recognise the huge contribution of the Sikh community to our business  culture and public life in Britain. I wish you and your families a very Happy Vaisakhi.   Waheguru Ji Ka Khalsa; Waheguru Ji Ki Fateh.
Important elections are approaching and if you’re not registered to vote  you won’t be able to take part.  Check now and make sure you can vote Labour on 5 May: https://www.gov.uk/register-to-vote

How can it be right that street cleaners  teaching assistants and nurses work and pay their taxes – yet some at the top think the rules don’t apply to them?  Yesterday David Cameron gave a statement to Parliament about the Panama Papers and the tax dodging scandal. His statement was a masterpiece in the art of distraction as he neglected to address the concerns of the public.  The Panama Papers confirm what people have increasingly felt - that there's one rule for the super rich and another for the rest.

David Cameron just gave a statement to Parliament about the Panama Papers and the tax dodging scandal.   His statement was a masterpiece in the art of distraction as he neglected to address the concerns of the public.  You know that the Panama Papers confirm that six years of crushing austerity could have been avoided if the Tory governments had made the super rich pay their taxes.

This morning I was interviewed on the Andrew Marr Show about David Cameron and the Panama Papers tax dodging scandal.  The revelations of industrial scale tax dodging and corruption from Panama haven’t just raised issues about the Prime Minister’s personal integrity. They also highlight his Government’s failure to take decisive action to crack down on tax avoidance and evasion.  As I said in this interview  the Panama Papers have shown there is one rule for the rich and one rule for the rest. If you're a care-worker  nurse  or street-cleaner you do not have the option of an offshore fund and a negotiated deal with HMRC.

I was interviewed on Sky about David Cameron and the Panama Papers tax dodging scandal.  The revelations of industrial scale tax dodging and corruption from Panama haven’t just raised issues about the Prime Minister’s personal integrity. They also highlight his Government’s failure to take decisive action  to crack down on tax avoidance and evasion.  Dodging taxes is a moral issue. It is taking money for schools and hospitals out of the pockets of working people. The government must now take decisive action against tax avoidance and evasion.

David Cameron said  "we're all in it together" but Labour's new research shows we're not.    Our cuts calculator exposes that the Tory cuts to local councils are hitting the poorest areas hardest.  Nine of the 10 most deprived councils in England are set to see cuts higher than the national average  with eight on course for cuts more than three times higher than national average. Today 3 million families would have been £1 000 worse-off if Osborne and Cameron had introduced their tax credit cuts.   The Labour Party defeated the Tories - we are standing up for families and communities across the country.  The failed Tory leadership has made unfair cuts that have hit the less well-off while standing by and failing to tackle tax avoidance by the very richest.
Long before the Panama Papers revelation  I asked David Cameron what he will do to tackle tax avoidance and evasion.   The response was Tory laughter and no action from Cameron.

The Labour Party launched our local elections campaign this morning and here's today's Party Election Broadcast.  David Cameron & George Osborne's failed and unfair leadership is making you and your family worse-off.   The failed Tory leadership has made unfair cuts that have hit the less well-off while standing by and failing to tackle tax avoidance by the very richest.  They have done this while failing our economy. The latest official forecasts show: growth down  earnings down  investment down  exports down and productivity down.   The Tories are on their own side  Labour is on your side.

The Labour Party launched our local elections campaign this morning.  Labour has made the Conservative government U-turn on working tax credits  police cuts and cuts to support for people with disabilities. Labour is standing up for communities against unfair Tory cuts - and for public investment  schools  housing and the NHS.  That's why we need to win across the country on 5th May.   The Panama Papers are a stark reminder that the Tories have failed to act against tax dodging  and are standing by while a wealthy elite get away without paying their way.

On this day in 1911  the suffragette Emily Wilding Davison was found in a cupboard in Westminster where she had hidden herself.   She did this to record her address on the night of the census as being 'The House of Commons' thus making her claim to the same political rights as men. This is just one of the many acts of the suffragettes which led to universal suffrage in 1928.   Emily Wilding Davison died in June 1913 from injuries sustained when she stepped in front of the King's horse at the Derby to draw attention to the public injustice suffered by women.   I had the pleasure of helping Tony Benn put up this plaque in the cupboard Emily hid herself in.

On the Andrew Marr Show this morning  John McDonnell explained that we need a Government that stands up for the UK Steel industry.  Labour's Shadow Chancellor laid out Labour's four point plan to save our steel industry.  1) Stabilise the industry and provide security for steelworkers – Tata must allow time for a buyer to be found and agreement to be reached  but if no new viable buyer is available in the short-term then nationalise to stabilise plants that face closure with the aim to place them on a secure foundation for the future.  2) Create a level playing field for steel – The Tories must stop blocking EU initiatives to introduce tariffs on cheap imported steel. And immediately initiate a review into tackling costs hitting the sector from high business rates and energy costs.  3) Fast-track key infrastructure projects requiring large amounts of steel – Set up an Emergency Investment Programme prioritising ‘shovel ready’ projects already in the government’s infrastructure pipeline which could help boost domestic demand.  4)Restructure the steel industry to make it more viable for the future needs of Britain – Engage with the workforce  management and customers to turn around the industry  laying out a strategy for the steel industry in the 21st century.

New research shows that the Tories forced academisation of all schools in England could cost £1.3 billion.   This unnecessary reorganisation is actually about the marketisation and asset-stripping of our education system.   As Lucy Powell Labour's Shadow Education Minister said  "Schools don't need this and parents  communities  teachers and school leaders don't want it - and now we find that it's going to cost over £1bn  money which could be better spent driving up standards."

Today we've launched a national advertising campaign highlighting David Cameron's failed leadership on steel.  David Cameron’s failed leadership is making British people worse off. The Tories have failed steelworkers while giving millionaires a handout of at least £42 000  The Tories are on their own side  Labour's on the side of the British people.
In just five hours 50 000 people have signed our petition to recall Parliament to address the steel crisis.  If you're not one of the 50 000 then sign our petition and #SaveOurSteel.

I've come to Port Talbot after the news that steel-making here is under threat  which puts thousands of jobs across the country and a strategic UK-wide industry at risk.  The Government must take action and the Labour Party is calling for immediate state intervention. I have written to David Cameron to urge him to recall Parliament so we can debate how to save the steel industry in Britain.  Please SIGN & SHARE our petition: https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/126128

Please SIGN & SHARE this petition to join me in calling for David Cameron to act to protect our steel industry and recall Parliament  It is essential that the Government intervenes to maintain steel production in Port Talbot  both for the workforce and the wider economy.

I have written to the Prime Minister to press for the recall of Parliament to debate the threat to the British steel industry and steelmaking at Port Talbot.  The news that Tata is preparing to pull out of steelmaking in Britain puts thousands of jobs across the country and a strategic UK-wide industry at risk. MPs must have the chance now to debate the future of steel and hold ministers to account for their failure to intervene.  Steelworkers and their families will be desperately worried about the uncertainty. The Government is in disarray over what action to take. Ministers must act now to protect the steel industry  which is at the heart of manufacturing in Britain and vital to its future.  It is essential that the Government intervenes to maintain steel production in Port Talbot  both for the workforce and the wider economy  if necessary by taking a public stake in the industry.  If necessary ministers must be prepared to use their powers to take a public stake in steelmaking to protect the industry and British manufacturing. The Government must do whatever it takes to save this strategic industry.

Women will be hit more than six times harder than men by George Osborne's changes to welfare and tax  according to fresh analysis published today.  Kate Green  Labour's Shadow Minister for Women and Equalities said in response:  "Yet again the government have exposed themselves as being strong on rhetoric but weak on action when it comes to equality and understanding the real  human impact of their policies.   86% of the net savings made through tax and benefit changes since 2010 will have come from women yet the government voted down Labour proposals in December to conduct an urgent cumulative gender impact assessment of their policies.  David Cameron and George Osborne could conduct this analysis if they wanted to make sure their polices are fair to women but they are choosing not to."

On Friday I spoke at the National Union of Teachers' Conference about Labour's opposition to Osborne's plans to force the academisation of all schools.   Instead of the Tory marketisation and asset-stripping of our education system  Labour wants schools to be accountable to their parents and communities.
A very happy Easter - peace  hope and social justice for all

At Prime Minister's Questions today  I asked David Cameron whether he would apologise for the anguish he caused across the disabled community by threatening to cut the support they receive.  He refused to say sorry  but said he would "learn the lessons". So why is he going ahead with a £30 per week cut for disabled people who receive Employment and Support Allowance?

Today  our thoughts and sympathies are with the people of Brussels.  We stand in solidarity with the victims of these horrific attacks  their friends and families  and the men and women of the emergency services.  We must defend our security and values in the face of such terrorist outrages  and refuse to be drawn into a cycle of violence and hatred.   We take pride in our societies of diverse faiths  races and creeds and will not allow those who seek to divide us to succeed.

George Osborne  the Chancellor of the Exchequer  should have been in Parliament today to answer questions about his Budget - which has unraveled in just a few days.   Osborne's Budget now lacks any credibility. Today  the Prime Minister attempted to defend his Chancellor's Budget when he should have been giving a statement about the refugee crisis.   George Osborne should have been in Parliament today.

This morning I was interviewed on Sky about George Osborne’s Budget  which proposed to slash support for disabled people while giving tax breaks to the wealthiest.   This is a Budget based on failure  with unfairness at its core that now lacks any credibility. It's time for Osborne to admit he's got it wrong and stand aside.

The resignation of Iain Duncan Smith reveals a Government in disarray and a Chancellor who has lost the credibility to manage the economy in the interests of the majority of our people.   The Budget has exposed George Osborne’s record of profound unfairness and economic failure. Not only must the cuts to support for disabled people be abandoned  but the Government must change economic course.   The Chancellor has failed the British people. He should follow the honourable course taken by Iain Duncan Smith and resign.

The Labour Party is standing up and demanding the Tories withdraw their planned cuts to Personal Independence Payments for people living with disabilities.  Osborne's Budget has unfairness at its very core. He's offering tax breaks to the wealthiest  whilst making it harder for people with disabilities to get the very basics like getting help to dress  leave the house  or go to the bathroom. Tomorrow I’ll be joining Labour Party activists who will be campaigning for Britain to remain in the European Union. Harold Wilson was born 100 years ago today. He was a Prime Minister who made Britain more equal - and there is no better accolade than that.   He was a proud Yorkshireman whose outlook was shaped by his experiences. He became an MP in 1945 when Labour was swept to power with a mandate to transform Britain through the introduction of the welfare state.   He is most remembered for radical changes to the law which gave people control of their own lives. In response to the Ford Dagenham machinists’ strike of 1968 – immortalised by the film Made in Dagenham – Wilson’s government passed the Equal Pay Act. His government boosted women’s equality by liberalising divorce laws and legalising abortion under certain conditions.   Crucial steps were taken by Wilson governments towards stopping discrimination against ethnic minorities and he ensured homosexuality was decriminalised. A seminal moment of Wilson’s social reforms was when he abolished capital punishment.   He famously tried to harness the ‘white heat of the technological revolution’ to modernise the British economy. He knew that a strong economy relied on a healthy and educated workforce. He prioritised the building of high quality homes for everyone and he created the Open University which – to this day – gives thousands of people opportunities to build successful careers with new qualifications.   One of his achievements  which is often forgotten  is his decision not to take Britain into the Vietnam War  despite huge pressure from the US president Lyndon Johnson.  His position as an internationalist was secured when he oversaw the independence of Zambia  Gambia  Zimbabwe  Botswana  Lesotho  Mauritius and Swaziland. This was no surprise to his peers as he was a member of the Movement for Colonial Freedom  now called Liberation  of which I was a Chair.   Harold Wilson’s accomplishments as Prime Minister demonstrate the best values of the British Labour Party: equality  internationalism  and social justice.   The year before his time as Prime Minister came to an end  Britain had the lowest levels of inequality in our history. That was his legacy  he made Britain more equal.

The NHS recording its worst ever performance in January is the result of six years of a Conservative government.   The NHS is under pressure as a direct result of decisions Tory Ministers have made. They cut older people’s home care  meaning hospitals have become dangerously full  and cuts to nurse training places have forced hospitals to drain resources hiring expensive agency staff.   As Labour's Shadow Health Secretary  Heidi Alexander  said earlier today: "Rather than take action to repair the damage they’ve done  Tory Ministers are taking a huge gamble with the future of our NHS. They’ve got no plan to tackle the financial crisis facing hospitals  and no plan to address the funding black hole in social care."

Join me in standing up for businesses and shop workers and keep Sundays special.    Today in Parliament MPs will vote on whether to allow large shops to open longer on Sundays. Longer opening would change the nature of Sunday forever  with millions more people being required to work more hours.  People could miss out on the things many of us only get to do on Sundays  whether practising their faith  Sunday lunch with family or watching the football game with friends - we all need some time off - let's keep Sunday special.  #SundayTrading

At midday I'll be back in the House of Commons and I'll be asking my 100th PMQs question as Labour leader - but I still won't get a straight answer from David Cameron.  When I was elected leader of the Labour Party last September I was determined to bring a new kind of politics to Westminster. And as part of that  I made a commitment to do Prime Minister’s Questions in a different way as well.  At one point David Cameron agreed that we should do things differently; he once said he was “fed up with the Punch and Judy politics of Westminster”. But the experience of the last six months suggests he has come to rather enjoy it.  From support for the steel industry  to cuts to flood defence schemes and the Tories’ cruel and unfair Bedroom Tax  David Cameron has been unable to defend his Government’s record at PMQs.  People want a different sort of politics. I’m determined to respond to that. Unfortunately  the Prime Minister has so far been unable to get beyond the political game-playing of the past.

Today's court ruling on Obamacare is a victory for the American people  and for House Republicans  who have consistently stood for the rule of law and against the unconstitutional actions taken by the Obama Administration. In the implementation of the health care law and many other significant matters  the Obama Administration has engaged in historic overreach that has exceeded the bounds of the president’s authority and deepened the distrust many Americans feel toward their government. The president of the United States is not a king or a monarch  with the ability to singlehandedly create or change the laws of our country.  And as I said in 2014 when I first announced we would initiate this legal action  the House has a responsibility to ensure the separation of powers in our democratic system remains clear  as the Framers intended.

I congratulate Donald Trump on securing his place as the Republican Party’s presumptive nominee. There is no doubt that he successfully tapped into the deep sense of anger and frustration so many Americans around the country rightfully feel today.   The tremendous anger of the current U.S. electorate – whether Republican  Democrat or independent – is a result of people fearful about the future  concerned with the direction of our country and tremendously frustrated by the abject failure and inability of leaders in Washington  D.C. to make anything better.   American voters have made it clear that Washington is broken  but I’m not optimistic that either of the leading candidates for President will put us on a better course.   The American Presidency is an office that goes beyond just politics. It requires of its occupant great fortitude and humility and the temperament and strong character to deal with the unexpected challenges that will inevitably impact our nation in the next four years.   Donald Trump has not demonstrated that temperament or strength of character. He has not displayed a respect for the Constitution. And  he is not a consistent conservative. These are all reasons why I cannot support his candidacy.   Hillary Clinton has proven to be an untrustworthy liberal politician who  if elected  would present a third term of the disastrous foreign and economic policy agenda of Barack Obama.   In November  I will not vote for Donald Trump or Hillary Clinton  but I will support principled conservatives at the state and federal levels  just as I have done my entire life. For Republicans  there is no greater priority than ensuring we keep control of both chambers of Congress. I look forward to working hard for great conservatives in the Senate and House in the coming months.

I wanted you all to be the first to know that today I am endorsing Ted Cruz for President.    Ted is a consistent  principled conservative who has demonstrated the ability to appeal to voters and win primary contests  including yesterday’s Utah caucus.   As I said from the moment I launched my presidential campaign  the stakes in 2016 couldn’t be higher.   Washington is broken  too many families are stuck in poverty and Western civilization is under attack from radical Islamic terrorists  as evidenced by the horrific attack in Brussels  which was preceded by attacks in Paris and California.   For the sake of our party and country  we must overcome the divisiveness and vulgarity Donald Trump has brought into the political arena or we will certainly lose our chance to defeat the Democratic nominee  most likely Hillary Clinton  this fall.    That is the only way we can reverse President Obama’s failed domestic and foreign policy agenda  and turn our country around.     Republicans can win back the White House and put our nation on a path to security and prosperity if we support a nominee who can unite our party and articulate how conservative policies will help people rise up and reach their full potential.   I hope you will join me in supporting Ted’s campaign by visiting www.tedcruz.org  and contributing and volunteering.

Twenty years ago today  the Black Hawk disaster took the lives of 18 soldiers from the Special Air Service Regiment and 5th Aviation Regiment.  This tragedy is the Army's single worst peace-time loss of life and shook the community here in Townsville and across Australia.    Today we remember and honour them. We stand in solidarity with the families and friends they left behind.   And we honour all the men and women of the ADF who continue to serve our nation with courage and distinction.

A great day for Centennial Park being nominated for assessment by the Heritage Council for inclusion on the National Heritage List. Centennial Park is an important part of our history  being the birthplace of our nation  where Federation was proclaimed and our first Commonwealth government sworn in.   It is also an important part of our local environment  enjoyed by millions of people every year.   If the Heritage Council approves its listing on the National Heritage List Centennial Park will receive additional recognition  protection and support from the Federal Government.

Congratulations to Maz and Rin Maslin on the birth of baby Violet.    Australia mourned when MH17 was shot down. 38 Australians were among 298 passengers and crew murdered. Maz and Rin are an inspiration to us all as they say that Violet’s birth is a testament “to our belief that love is stronger than hate”.

Youth unemployment is one of our biggest challenges.   It is a matter of shame that the Labor Party and the unions would seek to block a program that has been welcomed by the welfare sector   They understand that our program will ensure that young men and women who are struggling to get a job will get a start.   We are committed to jobs and growth.  Our program will provide 120 000 young people with the opportunity to get into work  get the experience of  work and become employable over the next four years.  Every element of our economic plan creates jobs and growth.

My Government is passionately committed to gender equality and we are working towards making that a practical reality.   Women on average retire with 35 per cent less in their super accounts than men and live longer.    It means less independence and less security in retirement.     Kirsten Barnett-Brown runs a business called KID Size Living.    She has been out of the workforce for three years  raising two young children  and is now building up her business.   We have to make it easier for Kirsten and millions of other women around Australia to catch up.     As part of the Budget  we have ensured that anyone with superannuation balances of $500 000 or less will be able to access their unused concessional contributions cap space on a rolling basis for a period of five years.    So it will be easier for women who have been out of the workforce to add to their superannuation at a concessional tax rate.

Professor Ross Crawford is - excuse the pun - at the cutting edge of knee surgery and hip replacements.    He is the first surgeon in the world to conduct a robotic enabled cemented hip replacement - meaning he can place a hip implant to within a millimetre of accuracy.    It means patients can be walking much sooner - often the same day - and it was estimated to is today that the greater accuracy and lower error rate will in the future save up to $4 000 for each procedure.    This is the type of collaborative innovation that will help Queensland University of Technology (QUT) working with industry and the hospital to take advanced robotics into more fields of surgery and medical diagnosis.    And with innovation and science a key part of our national economic plan  this makes for more productivity and more jobs and more growth from Australians' great ideas.
We want to ensure young people can get good jobs.   That is why our plan will spur growth in the small businesses that employ millions of Australians.
The election has been called for July 2.  Listen to our national economic plan for jobs and growth.

A few moments ago  I visited the Governor General and asked him to dissolve the Parliament in preparation for an election.    At 2.30pm  I will be addressing the nation to outline our plan for jobs and growth - watch it live on this page.

Thank heavens for all the mothers! Celebrate them  respect them and love them  today and every day.   What stronger  fiercer love can there be than a mother’s love?  I remember once when we were planting trees in a paddock and little Alex  not yet two  was playing nearby.   Lucy and I both looked up and saw a brown snake between us and Alex. Without a word she leapt through the air  over the snake  scooped up Alex and in another equally enormous bound was many metres away. It seemed to happen in an instant. I have never seen anyone move so fast.   Another time  smoke started to fill our house. Lucy  completely calm  woke me up. “There’s a fire. I’ll get the kids  you put out the fire.” And so we did.  And then when our children were sick  the best cure was wrapped in mummy’s arms. “You’re thermal  mummy.” Daisy used to say as she snuggled in.   Lucy’s love for children has always gone beyond her own.   She was an early chairman of the Sydney Children’s Hospital Foundation and together we have sought to help those who help sick or disadvantaged kids.   We both believe that those of us who are well  with healthy families  should count our blessings and wherever we can  reach out to help those who are not so fortunate.   Mothers’ Day is a time to recommit as parents to teach our sons to respect their mothers and sisters.  Disrespecting women doesn’t always end in violence against women  but that is where all violence against women begins.  And now we have two more mothers in our family. Our daughter Daisy and husband James have Jack  almost three and full of all the energy and mischief of small boys. And she is expecting another child in September.   Our son Alex and his wife Yvonne have a daughter  Isla  who is nearly one. They live in Singapore  but yesterday we chatted on facetime as though they were here - little Isla reaching out to touch us on the screen.  Daisy with Jack  Yvonne with Isla - another generation of mothers in our family  young women filled with a love as ancient as it is pure  a love that is so natural  so human it connects all of us today and from the beginning of time.

Never in our history has a Trade Minister clinched as many #export #trade deals with our top trading partners  as Andrew Robb.  Today  in his capacity as Special Envoy for Trade  he has brought home one last landmark deal with #Singapore
Fully supported  fully funded.

‘SHARE’ to spread the word to get our communities #NDISready  so people like Asha have choice and control of their lives.  We are investing early to improve outcomes later in life. At just 8 years old  Asha's mum and dad are working to give her the best start in life thanks to the NDIS.   In my time as Prime Minister I have secured agreements with all States and Territories for the roll out of the National Disability Insurance Scheme (NDIS).   We are fully committed to the NDIS and from July 1  we move from trials with 25 000 people benefiting from the scheme  scaling up to 460 000 participants by 2019.   As part of #Budget2016  my Government announced an #NDIS Savings Fund  where we will invest funds to fully fund the costs of rolling out the scheme.

It will set us up for the great economic opportunities of the 21st Century that await us - if we have the vision and the enterprise to take them.

That's why we're working to make sure our best teachers stay in classrooms rather than move on to other professions.  We’re also going to ensure that the money goes where it is needed most so that kids who need the most support get it as early as possible. Today the Coalition commits record levels of funding and a package of evidence based education reforms to drive excellence in Australia’s schools.  We will increase funding by 26.5 per cent by 2019-20 and target our investment in schools to achieve great outcomes for students.  We are focused on the importance of basic skills  such as maths and reading  and also on teacher quality.  Parents know that great teachers make all the difference.    This plan is fully funded and will ensure that every child receives the skills they need to secure jobs in the 21st century economy.

The great thing about being able to grow vegetables in a community rooftop garden is anyone can turnip.  Mat Pember runs the Pop Up Patch Garden on the roof of the Federation Square car park www.littleveggiepatchco.com.au  Better  greener  more livable cities lift us all.  We're doing our bit by building better infrastructure and making it easier for people to connect.    We're working towards a world where we could all get to work within 30 minutes - meaning more time to start growing some vegies!
Our cities are growing.  They need investment to manage growing pains such as congestion  affordability and pollution.
Port Arthur united us with a rare intensity.  We will never forget.

Twenty years ago today  the Port Arthur massacre shook our country.  Despite the years  despite some healing  the sense of loss still weighs heavily.  We will never be the same.  Standing against evil were countless acts of good  and tales of heroism—husbands dying protecting their wives; mothers dying protecting their children.   Those who risked their lives to warn others  who led people to safety  who did what they could to protect strangers.  At the funeral of Alannah and Madeline Mikac – aged just six and three – doves were released to signify that out of tragedy  we were united in our sincere desire that this kind of violence be prevented.    The Alannah & Madeline Foundation today continues its work to keep children safe from violence of any kind.  It will forever be a legacy of those who endured the massacre—those who died and those who survived—that gun violence in Australia is an exception rather than a brutal  regular reality.  We owe much to the leadership of John Howard for the tough gun laws that resulted and we are united with him when he says that we should be vigilant against any weakening of them today.

Amanda Schloss and Grace Thompson are great role models for women breaking down the barriers by working in construction.   Only one in 10 people working in the sector are women.    It's a huge waste of their potential.    To be a 21st Century economy we have to get more talented women like Amanda and Grace into jobs that have been traditionally dominating by men.    We're investing $250 000 for a pilot program to encourage women to get into construction and have people like Amanda and Grace mentor young women who are just starting out.    But we also need broader cultural change and that's why restoring the rule of law in construction is important.   No one should have to turn up to a work site where they face bullying  thuggery and intimidation.  We will restore a tough cop on the beat to make sure the rule of law is respected on work sites.

ABC's Fact Check unit has found the union ad campaign against the Australian Building and Construction Commission to be "nonsense".   Unlawful union activity in Australia's construction sector is a serious hand brake on economic growth.  Re-establishment of the building industry watchdog is an essential part of our plan to support jobs and growth.

Our commitment to building submarines in Australia will secure our island nation and help our economy transition into the 21st Century.  ‘SHARE’ if you support Australian workers building Australian submarines.
BREAKING: Today we announce Australia's submarine fleet will be built locally  ensuring our economic and national security.  Australian built.  Australian jobs.  Australian steel.

As we continue the Centenary of Anzac  it’s time to reflect on the impact on our nation of the extraordinary sacrifice at Fromelles and the other battlegrounds of the Western Front.  We became a nation that does not glorify war - this day does not commemorate a triumph of arms.   Anzac Day commemorates the triumph of the human spirit  the courage and resolve of those men and women who 100 years ago and ever since and today put their lives on the line to keep us safe  free and defend the values of democracy  freedom and the rule of law which we share and for which we stand.

We do not boast of our victories  because we know that they came at a cost—to us and to others.  We do not parade missiles and tanks in an ostentatious display of might; we choose to stand as one in a moment of silent contemplation in tribute to those who fought and died so that we could live in freedom."  #LestWeForget   Photo: Australian Army

Sergeant Garry Robinson lost three of his closest friends and comrades in arms when his Black Hawk helicopter crashed in Afghanistan in 2010.   He suffered a severe brain injury and his long and difficult recovery over four and a half years had many set backs - including the amputation of a leg.    Garry embodies the Anzac spirit - his courage and professionalism while on active duty and his courage and resilience and sheer guts as he worked to overcome his terrible injuries.    All throughout his long recovery  Garry said it was the love of his wife Katrina and their children and the memory of his fallen mates that gave him the strength to pull through.    Next month  he will be representing Australia in the Invictus Games  competing with other wounded veterans in events that most of us would struggle to keep up in.    Our freedoms  our  Australian way of life  have been hard won by generations of Australian servicemen and women who have put their lives on the line to keep Australia safe.   This Anzac Day as we attend ceremonies throughout the country  we are reminded that we honour the veterans of 1916 by supporting and caring for  the veterans of 2016 and their families.  Donate to some of the charities who support our veterans:  Soldier On:  https://donation.giveeasy.org/soldier-on  RSL: http://rsl.org.au/support-us  Legacy:  https://www.legacy.com.au/donate
Lest we forget.

Kim and Julian Mignacca have used negative gearing to buy property and invest in their family's future.   Kim is a social worker and Julian is a plumber.  They are a young couple with a baby girl and they have invested in real estate in order to get ahead.  They are like thousands of other Australians who negative gear - two thirds of whom have a taxable income of less than $80 000 a year.   Labor wants to eliminate negative gearing on existing residential property  commercial property  shares- in fact on every type of asset except a new dwelling.    This will reduce property values  it will increase rents and it will make it harder for people to get ahead.   And if that's not bad enough  Labor wants to increase  capital gains tax by 50 per cent which will mean less investment right across the board.   My Government wants more investment and more jobs. We will not change the negative gearing rules nor will we increase capital gains tax.   The enterprising spirit of Australians like the Mignaccas is what secures our economic future and the jobs of our children and grandchildren in the years ahead.   We will always back those people who back themselves  their business  and their family's future.
Great to see Max & his dad Sam at the barber's shop. Best way to get a haircut - wrapped in the Wiggles & watching ABC Kids on dad's phone!

BREAKING: Australia has signed a new global climate agreement.  It is an agreement that will drive humanity’s capacity for inventiveness and a new wave of technological advances.  It's good for our environment  good for our economies.  We will cut emissions by 26 to 28 per cent below 2005 levels by 2030.  We will also contribute at least $1 billion over the next five years from our existing aid budget both to build climate resilience and reduce emissions.

Tonight is the first night of Passover - the festival when Jewish people remember the Exodus when the Israelites were freed from bondage in Egypt and after years of wandering in the desert were led by Moses to their promised land. It is a heroic story of liberation  hopes raised and dashed and then  against all odds  fulfilled. A story of courage and of faith  of endurance and resilience.   Lucy and I wish all the Jewish communities a very warm Chag Sameach as families gather around the seder table and tell again an ancient story  as old as history but as timeless as the values it evokes.

It’s not every day you see a big rig outside of Parliament.  Alina Hawkins runs a family livestock transport business from her home near Echuca.   A few weeks ago  she began protesting against an order by a Tribunal that threatened the viability of her business – and tens of thousands of other businesses around Australia.  It's unlikely you would ever meet a more passionate campaigner.   Last night we abolished the Tribunal to protect tens of thousands of owner drivers and the communities they support.

BREAKING: Parliament has just abolished the #RSRT to keep tens of thousands of owner truck drivers on the road and to protect their livelihoods.  I have met hundreds of them in recent days.  Their determination  their enterprise  their hard work drives our country.  'SHARE’ if you support small business in Australia and back people who like our owner drivers  are willing to back themselves
We're with you #RSRT
The energy  the enthusiasm  the enterprise of small business underpins our future.  That's why we're backing owner truck drivers by abolishing the #RSRT

Darvill Malcolm was a larger than life man. He was the President of the Rose Bay RSL Sub-Branch and a forceful advocate for veterans in my electorate.  Sadly  Darvill passed away over Christmas but I was able to pay my respects to him and all our other service personnel at the ANZAC Sunday Service at Rose Bay RSL.   On ANZAC Sunday  Darvill could always be found at the head of the march  even when he lost the use of his legs he'd still be out in front on his motorised scooter.   Darvill's wife Marie  who affectionately knew him as 'Darvill the Marvel' led the tributes for a man who had a genuine love for his country and his local community. He will be sorely missed.

Heather Jones started driving trucks in Karratha a bit over 25 years ago and started her own trucking company in 2004.  She has spent much of that time pushing for cultural change in the industry – such as encouraging more women to become truck drivers and for greater safety standards.    She is now campaigning against the tribunal that threatens the viability of tens of thousand of owner truck drivers across the country:  "Independence in running my own company is really important to me because I need to be able to do a variety of jobs for a variety of clients  I need to be able to financially quote for those jobs and be competitive " she said.    “The payments order is a two-edged sword.  On the east coast  the higher rates will send the smaller companies into bankruptcy with many already being told they no longer have a contract!  And on the west coast  it will mean that the hirer will be able to say  this is the base rate the Government has set.  So those of us who really need to charge more to cover our higher costs in the country will have to drop our rates.  We can’t afford to do that.   “I don’t believe the payments order system will make the roads safer because there’s no evidence that it will.  I support abolishing the RSRT.”

The size and scale of the Barrow Island LNG project has to be seen to be believed.   The partnership between industry  community and the state and federal governments is world class and will contribute to driving down global carbon emissions.

Our Government will abolish the Tribunal that Bill Shorten set up that will force tens of thousands of owner truck drivers out of business.  We will use the $4 million a year saved to fund road safety initiatives that will make a real contribution to reducing road accidents.  We believe owner drivers should  be able to set their own rates.  We reject Labor's way that a Government tribunal dictates the rates of small family businesses while big trucking companies can charge whatever they like.  Pauline and Glen Kearney started a trucking business 20 years ago.  They own two trucks which they drive with their son Matt (their other son Jack hopes to join the business when he's old enough).    Australia thrives when people like Pauline and Glen have a go - when they raise money  when they invest and work hard to build up their business.  Because of a deal Bill Shorten made with the Transport Workers Union they are being forced out of business  along with tens of thousands of other truck owner drivers.  We back Pauline and Glen and the thousands of other owner drivers - small businessmen and women  family businesses. We will always back those Australians who have backed themselves and whose enterprise is securing our prosperity and the economic growth on which our future depends.

A sad reminder that immunisation is the safest and most effective way of protecting against vaccine-preventable diseases.  'SHARE' this to get the message out about the need for immunisation.  Thanks to this brave mum for speaking out and helping to educate other parents. Our thoughts and prayers are with Cormit and her family and we hope that baby Eva is able to make a speedy recovery.  The whooping cough vaccination is recommended to pregnant women in their third trimester and it is free of charge through each of the State and Territories' vaccination programs.  For immunisation to provide the greatest benefit  a sufficient number of people need to be vaccinated to halt the spread of disease and achieve community immunity.  Flu vaccinations are recommended for women at any stage of their pregnancy. Through the National Immunisation Program  flu vaccines are also free of charge.  The Government’s No Jab No Pay measure is one of a range of measures the Government has implemented to improve immunisation coverage rates.  For more information on the whooping cough vaccine  visit: http://www.immunise.health.gov.au/…/…/Content/pregnant-women

The Kenbi claim made by the Larrakia people of the Cox Peninsula near Darwin have one of the oldest running native title claims in Australia’s history.   It was lodged in 1979 and has not been settled in almost 40 years.   Despite the injustices and the trauma  aboriginal communities like the Larrakia people have shown the greatest tenacity and resilience.   Today Minister Nigel Scullion and NT Chief Minister Adam Giles met with Raylene Singh and traditional owners who have led the Kenbi claim  and they have given their consent to a proposal made by the Federal Government to settle the claim.   In accepting freehold title over their land  the traditional owners will have the ability to develop the land economically.   Economic development led by Aboriginal people is a vital foundation of true empowerment.   It’s a practical example of how we can work together to recognise Indigenous peoples’ enduring connection to the land and help empower Indigenous communities.

Australia’s governments must work together to solve the big issues.   Our economic plan is designed to ensure that as our economy transitions from the mining boom to the new economy  we continue to deliver the vital services and infrastructure Australians expect.  The focus of governments should be about delivering better services – not arguing over funding.  We are all sick of it.   A way to solve these arguments would be to give states a proportion of personal income tax - rather than demanding money from Canberra they would be raising money themselves and be accountable to their own voters.

As parents  universally  we want more for our children than was afforded to us by our own parents and society.    We want our children to have opportunities that perhaps we didn’t have.  The Close the Gap campaign is a grassroots movement has shaped  and will continue to shape  policy across governments.  Importantly  it will ensure that Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander babies born today live longer  are healthier and have more opportunities to live their full potential.  That is something that should fill us with optimism about our future.  We reflect on the gains we are making on Indigenous health and the challenges that still remain. The target to halve the gap in child mortality is on track.   The Indigenous infant mortality rate has more than halved over the past 16 years.   Between 2010 and 2013  the proportion of Indigenous mothers who attended antenatal care in the first trimester of pregnancy increased to 52 per cent. Rates were highest in very remote areas (59 per cent).   By the age of five a higher percentage of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander children are immunised compared with other Australian children.   While the life expectancy target is not on track to be met  some longer term improvements are evident.    For example  Indigenous mortality rates from circulatory diseases (such as heart disease and stroke) declined by 41 per cent between 1998 and 2013.   In the last decade  there has been a 7 percentage point decline in smoking rates for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people aged 15 years and over.  There is much more to be done.   But today  we say thank you to all those who work with Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Australians and communities to improve the lives of our First Australians #closethegap

This morning at the inaugural National Family Violence Summit I paid tribute to Tara Costigan. I have written to my local party members regarding Jeremy Corbyn's leadership of the Labour Party:  Dear Labour member   I am writing to explain to you why I have today called on Jeremy Corbyn to stand down as Leader of the Labour Party.  I have been loyal to Jeremy throughout his tenure as Leader. I resisted calls to speak out against him when he was running for the job and since he was elected. I have backed him 100%.  But my constituents and the country urgently need an effective  united Labour party to try and chart a progressive way forward for Britain after our exit from the European Union. We face grave economic risks and huge uncertainty. The situation has become untenable because the overwhelming majority of members of the Parliamentary party have lost confidence in him.  This is not ideological----the opposition to him is from all wings of the PLP. It is certainly not about a ‘Blairite’ wing of the party. I believe Jeremy’s views on austerity and inequality are important for the future of the party.   Nor is it unconstitutional---our constitution specifically provides for a Leader needing the support of the parliamentary party and the party in the country. The constitution says that if a Leader loses the support of 20% of the Parliamentary party and they nominate another candidate  there should be a fresh ballot. Jeremy has lost the support of more than 75% of the PLP.  I understand my position will upset some party members. Some who support Jeremy and some who fear this is a distraction from the crisis the country faces. To supporters of Jeremy  my candid view is that a progressive  Left agenda is more likely to be taken forward in a united Labour Party  not a wrecked  divided party. And to those who worry about distraction  we cannot function as an effective Opposition in the current circumstances.  Jeremy has had a profound and lasting influence on the debate about who we are as a party and the causes we need to fight for. I know he is someone who cares deeply about those causes  our party and our country. I hope he will reflect on how he can best serve this agenda at this critical moment for Britain and the Labour Party.  With best wishes  Ed Miliband

If you travel to the Australian War Memorial in Canberra you will find the name Eliazar Margolin on the memorial wall - a Russian ANZAC.  He was one of around 1000 Russians who fought alongside Australia in WW1.  I visited an exhibition in St Petersburg honouring their service.

As President of the think tank  Asia Society Policy Institute I focus on hard policy issues facing the Asian region  such as East Asian security architecture.   And Russia is part of Asia  however it defines itself  and its interests lie in Asia.  The past few days I have been attending the St. Petersburg International Economic Forum and joined in fascinating discussions on the region's and the globe's energy future.

Nothing I love more than catching up with fellow Aussies in far flung places.  #aussiesabroad  And who should I meet in the Grand Place in Brussels this week but Felice Arena - highly esteemed author and illustrator of Specky Magee and the Farticus Maximus books and more.   What can I say  it was an honour.

Have been attending the Saint Petersburg International Economic Forum this week.  St. Petersburg International Economic Forum is an annual international conference dedicated to economic and business issues - looking at not just economic issues facing Russia  but emerging markets and the world as a whole. We at the Asia Society  at the invitation of the King of Belgium  have just concluded the Brussels Asia Rising dialogue.   This is an effort to bring together thought leaders from Europe  Asia and the U.S. trilaterally to discuss and debate where they can cooperate in sustaining a stable future global order.   We debated security policy collaboration and how to re-energize global economic growth; effective actions to reduce the threat of violent extremism and terrorism; post-Paris Accord action on climate change and the best global approaches to managing the exploding scale of global people movements  including the future of the UNHCR.   We have agreed that this will be the first in a series of such dialogues  convened at the invitation of the King of the Belgians  the Belgian government and the Asia Society.

Spoke at the International Peace Institute Vienna Seminar #IPIVS16 on declining global political support for the United Nations and what to do about it.    Namely better delivery for member states and their peoples. #foraneffectiveUN

Have been part of an International Peace Institute conference in Vienna  looking at how the United Nations and its Member States can further unite their strengths for peace.   It was a wide-ranging discussion looking at the impact and role of women in armed conflict; the need for the United Nations to better communicate its message to governments and citizens on the great work the UN does; and also the fundamental reform required for the UN refugees system.

Today is #WorldNoTobaccoDay.   And this year's global campaign by the World Health Organization (WHO) is focused on #PlainPackaging.  Begun by my Government  against all the vested interests of international #bigtobacco  it is now being adopted across the world.  Law in the UK and France  and now its introduction is being discussed in Norway  NZ  Indonesia  South Africa  and more  because it works.  But ultimately  it comes down to you. There's no time like the present. Quit.  Believe in yourself.  You can do it.

Meet Desmond Tutu's grandson  Lizo Tutu.   Guess what? He's decided not to be a politician.   He's decided not to become a priest.   He wants to become a professional golfer.   Caught up with him at St. George's Cathedral  with his granddad.

Went to Cape Town to say thank you to one of the global heroes of reconciliation - Archbishop Desmond Tutu .   He's 84.   Despite health challenges  he stood and presided over an hour-and-quarter service at St. George's Cathedral.   He then personally greeted all those attending from near and far. And then was gracious enough to wander down the street and sit down for coffee.   A remarkably inspiring individual.   I thanked him for the inspiration he provided me in framing the National Apology to Indigenous Australians.   His only complaint to me was that Aus beat SA too often in the cricket. And could I do something about it... I respectfully declined

I am thrilled that my tea blend has helped raise funds for the RSPCA to the tune of half a million dollars.    This money means that the RSPCA has been able to focus on saving the lives of animals who are injured; it means that pets who are abandoned have a shelter that takes care of them; and supports a critical new service where pets can be sheltered when women fleeing domestic violence need safe refuge and want to ensure their pets are safe too.  All those cups of Australian Afternoon Tea have added up to a real difference to the lives of our furry friends.    I'm extremely saddened to hear that Twinings has stopped giving 10 cents from each box of Australian Afternoon Tea to the RSPCA. I hope they change their mind. #haveaheartTwinings

The SWA meeting has drawn to a close - but the work doesn't end.    I also just wanted to give a shout out to the Fred Hollows Foundation doing great work in Ethiopia treating trachoma.   Trachoma is a disease of poverty  and a disease of poor sanitation.  It is threatens the eyesight of hundreds of thousands of Ethiopians.    I want to thank Fred Hollows for everything they are doing - in both treating and training.  But it is up to us to put an end to trachoma before it even starts.  Trachoma is just one of the many many debilitating effects of poor sanitation.   And with the will - working together - we can truly change millions of lives for the better.  http://www.hollows.org/  https://www.facebook.com/FredHollows/

Ministers from across the world are gathered in Addis Ababa over the next days to combine forces in the practical business of trying to save millions of lives each year through improved water and sanitation for all.
