Met with high schoolers  advocates and researchers at U of M's Roadway Safety Institute to highlight the dangers of distracted driving. We tried an amazing driving simulator that shows how dangerous distractions are. The transportation bill signed into law in December included my provisions to fight distracted driving. Last year  texting and other distractions contributed to at least 74 deaths on Minnesota roads.

Senator Tammy Baldwin and I met with students  graduates and educators at Hennepin Technical College and across the river in Hudson  Wisconsin  to discuss college affordability. We are sponsors of the In the Red Act  which would help student loan borrowers refinance their debt  strengthen Pell Grants  and invest in community and technical colleges. The bill is fully paid for by closing special interest tax loopholes.

It's nearly pool season  and that means it's pool safety season too. That's why Abbey's Hope -- named in honor of 6-year-old Abigail Taylor  who died in 2008 from serious injuries she received from a faulty pool drain -- has released a new PSA on drowning. Please watch it and share:

I wanted to share my New York Times editorial on distracted driving. My bipartisan initiatives  included in the last two transportation bills  encourage states to enact graduated licensing programs and increase funding for states to enact and enforce distracted driving laws. In April  Minnesota police officers issued nearly 1 000 citations for texting while driving during a weeklong enforcement effort.

This week I spoke on the Senate floor on the need for action to combat the Zika virus. The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention has reported nearly 900 cases of the Zika virus in the U.S. and U.S. territories  and a Puerto Rican man infected with the virus has died. It's only a matter of hours or days or weeks before an American citizen in the continental U.S. gets the disease from a mosquito here. We can't just sit and wait until it happens. We need to be ready.

This week the Senate passed my (purple-texted) resolution with Senator Al Franken honoring Prince. All senators can agree on this: Prince was a one-of-a-kind artist  fiercely independent and uniquely talented. For Minnesotans  Prince was our superstar next door. He made "Purple Rain" a household name  First Avenue a landmark  and brought international fame to Minnesota's music scene. He will be missed.

Kari’s Law  which I introduced with Republican Senator Deb Fischer  passed the Commerce Committee yesterday. It ensures that new multi-line phone systems let a person who dials 9-1-1 reach help without dialing a prefix. It's named for Kari Hunt  who was stabbed in a hotel. Her 9-year-old daughter called 9-1-1 but couldn't connect because she didn't dial 9 first. Kari later died. Time to pass this law and save lives.

John Anderson of Willmar was killed in action on D-Day. His family was told his remains had been washed out to sea. But after research by John's nephew  the family asked that an unmarked grave in Normandy be disinterred. The Pentagon said no -- twice. After I wrote in support of the request  the Navy tested the remains  which were positively identified. 72 years later  John will finally be laid to rest in Minnesota.

Senator Patrick Leahy of Vermont  ranking member of the Senate Judiciary Committee  and I held a roundtable discussion today on the Violence Against Women Act at the Tubman Center. We worked together to pass the 2013 VAWA reauthorization  which included my provision to strengthen federal stalking laws. Community leaders and local advocates shared what improvements they would like to see made in the next Congress.

Wanted to share my interview with Esme Murphy this morning. I talked about Prince  airports  and my burn pit legislation. Many believe the smoke produced from the burning of waste on military bases in Iraq and Afghanistan has exposed servicemembers to harm. My bipartisan bill would create a center of excellence within the VA in the prevention  diagnosis  treatment  and rehabilitation of related health conditions.

I wanted to share the speech I gave yesterday honoring Minnesota legend Prince. As I said on the floor of the Senate  our world is a whole lot cooler because Prince was in it  and it's a whole lot sadder now that he's gone.

Like all Minnesotans I am shocked and saddened today. I grew up with Prince's music. He was a superstar composer  an amazing performer and a music innovator with a fierce belief in the independence of his art. He made "Purple Rain" a household name  First Avenue a landmark  and brought international fame to Minnesota's music scene. I was always so proud to say  "Prince  he is from Minnesota." We grieve his loss today.

Good news: The Senate passed bipartisan legislation to reauthorize the Federal Aviation Administration. From tourism to manufacturing  when we improve our air travel system  we make it that much easier for people to travel and goods to ship  benefiting our entire economy. The legislation included provisions I pushed for to improve safety  streamline certification rules for aviation manufacturers  support small airports  and require training for flight attendants to recognize and report human trafficking. This vote brings us one step closer to a better  stronger  and safer aviation industry.

This week I called for passage of emergency funding to fight the Zika virus outbreak. More than 800 Americans from 40 states  including Minnesota  have contracted the virus while traveling abroad. The CDC has confirmed a link between Zika infection during pregnancy and severe birth defects like microcephaly. The Senate must pass this emergency funding request as soon as possible so the United States can help fight the spread of Zika and treat those who have been infected.

I wanted to share this piece on how new energy-efficiency standards for light bulbs have sparked innovation and now are saving consumers a lot of money. It's true: Sometimes progress does start in Congress.  http://www.startribune.com/opinion/commentaries/375420421.html

Today I met with members of Minnesota's Muslim community to discuss what all of us can do to increase understanding among faiths and cultures in our community. One person told the story of their young child's reaction to being told to "go home" by an angry person ... "we are home " she said. A reminder through the innocent words of a child: people of many faiths call our country home.

This week Senator Boxer and I were joined by "Miracle on the Hudson" Capt. Sully Sullenberger and cargo pilot Lee Collins to discuss the Safe Skies Act  which creates a uniform rest standard for pilots. Cargo pilots are exempted from fatigue rules put in place after the Colgan Flight 3407 crash despite the fact that planes share the same airspace and airports whether they carry passengers or cargo.

(Un)happy Equal Pay Day -- the symbolic day when American women finally earn as much as men doing the same job earned the year before. Women on average still only earn 79 cents for every dollar men make. This gap shortchanges a typical American woman by about $10 000 per year. That's bad news for women  our families and our economy. That's why I've cosponsored the Paycheck Fairness Act every Congress that I've been a senator. It's time to close this gap for good.

Happy Birthday to my dad  Jim Klobuchar  who turns 88 today. 88 is a magic number  Dad ... not only was it the Vikings' great Alan Page's number  it's also the exact number of keys on the piano  something you've been known to play from time to time! I know my dad would want to hear from all of you  so please reply with greetings  and I'll share them with him!

Happy National Beer Day! (In case you needed another reason to try one of Minnesota's great beers.) And it's not just Minnesotans who think we have something special brewing here. In fact  two of our companies -- August Schell of New Ulm and Summit in St. Paul -- are among the top 50 in sales of craft brews nationwide. Cheers!

Today I led a Steering Committee roundtable discussion with state and local officials on the impact the vacancy on the U.S. Supreme Court could have on communities across the country. Leaving the seat open until next year would be the longest vacancy in 100 years. The Supreme Court has the constitutional responsibility to weigh some of the top issues facing the American people — its decisions affect people’s daily lives. This is not the way our nation’s highest court should operate. The Senate must do its job and hold hearings.

Great to speak at the steps of the Supreme Court today with a number of my colleagues  including Senator Tammy Baldwin. You know that old show "Eight is Enough"? Well  eight isn't enough when we're talking about Supreme Court justices. Their decisions affect Americans every day  and we need nine.

Today a group of my Senate colleagues and I -- joined by Department of Homeland Security Secretary Jeh Johnson -- announced legislation to improve airport security. Following the tragic terror attacks at the Brussels Airport  security officials must be given the common sense tools they need to keep passengers safe. As I said recently at Minneapolis-St. Paul International Airport  we need to ensure passenger safety without hurting efficiency. This legislation will increase the presence of security personnel patrolling the "soft" target areas at our airports -- such as baggage claim and check-in -- that could be the most susceptible to attack.

Yesterday Sheriff Rich Stanek  Senator Chris Eaton  Representative Bob Barrett  Walgreens leadership and I were in Brooklyn Center to discuss how drug takeback programs can fight prescription drug abuse. My bill that passed the Senate expands access to disposal programs  and Walgreens plans to install disposal kiosks in 500 stores. But the Legislature must act before Minnesota stores can take part in the program.

Was in Brainerd yesterday for a roundtable discussion on drug courts and how they can help non-violent offenders become productive members of society. That's what's happening in Crow Wing County. It was inspiring to see how drug court participants and graduates there are supporting one another and helping each other recover

Yesterday I held an opioid roundtable with Moorhead officials and Minnesota families hurt by addiction. Casey Jo Schulte of Montevideo was a talented swimmer studying to become a nurse like her mother  Shelly. After multiple surgeries and prescription opioids for chronic pain  she became addicted and began using heroin. She's not alone -- four out of five heroin users started out misusing prescription painkillers. In Casey Jo's case  it cost her her life. Casey Jo died last August at age 26. Stories like hers are why I introduced the bipartisan Comprehensive Addiction and Recovery Act  which recently passed the Senate and provides new tools to fight addiction and get treatment for people who need it. It's time to focus on treatment  resources  and drug monitoring before more lives are lost.

I was honored to speak today at an event celebrating the new partnership between two amazing institutions -- the Humphrey School of Public Affairs and the Stimson Center  a nonpartisan public policy institute based in D.C. Great crowd -- more than 300 people were on hand to hear about the challenges our nation faces in a changing world.

Enjoyed speaking today at the launch of  the Engage Cuba Minnesota State Council. This council and its members will help promote common-sense policy changes that will boost American agriculture and business and at the same time help the people of Cuba. I've introduced bipartisan legislation to lift the embargo. I’m proud that Minnesota is leading the way on working with Cuba.

Happy Easter  and happy spring! Here's a photo of me at age one surrounded by some fuzzy friends. That bunny in the back always seemed like a giant and now I know why -- it was larger than I was!  Easter  Passover and spring are a time to reflect on faith  sacrifice  and new beginnings. I hope you have a wonderful Sunday with your family and friends.

Sometimes in the Senate we do big things that help a lot of people. And sometimes we do small things that help one person but make a big difference in their lives. I'm so glad my staff was able to help 89-year-old veteran Ray Morgan of Cottage Grove (who was born at home in 1926 with no official records of his birth save his baptism) get his passport and keep his 90th birthday trip to Canada on track. Have fun  Ray!

VA Secretary Bob McDonald is in Minnesota  and yesterday we were at the Minneapolis VA meeting about the challenges in our veterans' healthcare system and the work that needs to be done to fix it. Today  Secretary McDonald  Congressman Emmer  Congressman Walz  and I are at a town hall meeting with employees at the St. Cloud VA. Our veterans deserve the best care -- they have earned it.

Today I met with Judge Merrick Garland  President Obama's Supreme Court nominee. His record as a jurist is exemplary  and his credentials have been widely praised by Democrats and Republicans. I was impressed with his knowledge of the law and his commitment to finding common ground. It's time for the Senate to hold a public confirmation hearing followed by an up-or-down vote. Thanks to C-SPAN for sharing the photo.

I am deeply saddened by the terrorist attacks in Brussels  and my heart goes out to the victims and their families. Along with our allies  we must be relentless in our work to combat terrorism and extremism and to root out the evil in our midst. Belgium is our nation's friend  and Americans stand with the Belgian people.

It’s good to be here in Cuba. Cubans are excited about the President’s visit! We need to pass my bipartisan bill to lift the embargo. Here is an interview Republican Senator Jeff Flake and I did together today on passing our legislation. Let’s get it done.

Great to join my labor friends (very early!) this morning for the Water’s Off Kickoff Breakfast. Each year  union plumbers donate their time and talent to repair plumbing issues for people in need. It’s just one example of how unions make our community stronger.

This week the Senate Health  Education  Labor  and Pensions Committee passed the Anna Westin Act  bipartisan legislation I introduced with Senators Shelly Moore Capito  Kelly Ayotte  and Tammy Baldwin. The legislation is named in honor of Anna Westin  a native of Chaska who died of anorexia at age 21. Millions of Americans suffer from eating disorders  but very few get the help they need to recover. This vote brings us one step closer to passing legislation that will help people get treatment and prevent future tragedies.

Yesterday a bipartisan group of my colleagues and I pressed the Army to change its policy and once again allow Women Airforce Service Pilots to be buried at Arlington National Cemetery. These brave women piloted every kind of military aircraft and logged 60 million miles flying missions across the United States during World War II. Last week we lost one of the last remaining WASPs  96-year-old Betty Strohfus of Faribault. She and the other WASPs served bravely and earned a spot in Arlington. We cannot change history  but we can change how brave women like Betty are honored today.

Honored to be in the Rose Garden today when President Obama nominated Judge Merrick Garland for the Supreme Court. I have met Judge Garland several times  and I am impressed by his record and background as well as his ability to gain bipartisan support with his 76-23 Senate vote for the D.C. Circuit. The President has done his job in nominating this exemplary jurist. Now we need to do our job in the Senate.

I wanted to share some sad news. Former U.S. Representative Martin Sabo has died at age 78. Martin was my friend and mentor as he was to so many who learned their politics the Martin Sabo way: do what is best for your district  stand up for the people you represent  and don't forget to have some fun while you're at it.  At a time when our politics has become increasingly coarse  Martin knew how to be strong but civil  effective but kind. In his quiet Scandinavian way  he was a fierce progressive who got things done for his district and our state. And whether it was playing on the congressional softball team or bringing home the funding for a road or a housing project  Martin Sabo truly enjoyed his work.   In my early days in politics  Congressman Sabo never minded if I tagged along with him to his Minnehaha Park picnics or senior citizen door knocks  and  even though my last name was twice as long as his  he agreed to do joint lawn signs when I first ran for county attorney. He was a veteran congressman and I was a political rookie  but he didn't hesitate to help. He saw it as part of his job to help young people get started in politics. And Martin was so popular that those signs may have well been the reason I won (by less than nine votes per precinct!) that first election.  Martin was an extraordinary and exemplary public servant who also stayed active and involved in his community after leaving office. He rarely missed a major gathering or a political event  especially if it involved his beloved Norway.  My thoughts and prayers are with Sylvia and all of Martin's family.

TSA head Peter Neffenger joined me Friday at Minneapolis-St. Paul Airport. Last Sunday I met with MSP officials and asked him to visit to see how wait times affect travelers and to discuss solutions  such as more canine teams and screeners. Minnesota travelers funded TSA at its requested budget and deserve better than hour-long lines. He vowed to fix it. Also  thanks to TSA workers for what you do.

Congratulations to 3M on its amazing new research and development center in Maplewood. I had a chance to speak at the opening ceremony today and tour the new building. It's the size of more than eight football fields -- big enough for nearly 700 scientists! Always glad to see companies investing in good jobs right here in Minnesota.

Good to welcome Prime Minister Trudeau to the U.S. -- and discuss hockey! As co-chair of the Canada-U.S. InterParliamentary Group  I’ve been working with Canadian officials for years on issues from the border to the Great Lakes to timber. Prime Minister Trudeau brings new excitement to this longstanding friendship. Today I met with the Prime Minister and a small group of senators and will attend the State Dinner.

Bernie Brommer  former President of the Minnesota AFL-CIO  and someone I got to know when I first got into politics  died this week. Here's an interesting fact: Brommer created the AFL-CIO’s first full-time organizing position in our state. Sending my deepest condolences to his friends and family and Minnesota's workers.

Yesterday I called on the Departments of Treasury and Commerce to allow American hotels to operate in Cuba. Airbnb has more than 2 000 listings  but U.S. hotels cannot operate in Cuba due to Treasury and Commerce regulations. Hotel operators from Spain and the U.K. are planning to build hotels in Cuba. Continuing to isolate Cuba will be contrary to Cuba's interests and our interests  and disadvantage American workers.
A thought provoking NAIDOC Week launch of the "Gallery of the First Tasmanians" at QVMAG. With Chair of QVMAG Aboriginal Reference Group  Patsy Cameron and Project Manager  Greg Lehman.

We now have 5 Tasmanians off to the Rio 2016 Olympic Games!  Eddie Ockenden and Tim Deavin will be on the Hockey field  while cycling sensations Richie Porte  Amy Cure and Georgia Baker will be racing for the Men’s and Woman’s cycling teams. They join a select few athletes who have represented Tasmania at the Olympics since 1912.  With just 31 days until the opening of the Games  please join with me in supporting our Tasmanian athletes who'll represent the country on the world stage!

National NAIDOC Week kicks off this week - a time to celebrate Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander history  culture and achievements as well as recognise the contributions that Indigenous Australians make to our country and our society.  I encourage everyone to check out NAIDOC events happening around the state here: http://www.aroundyou.com.au/tasmania/tags/naidoc-week/whats-on

The flagship of Tasmania’s nation leading $26 million Family Violence Action Plan  the Safe Families Tasmanian Coordination Unit  is now fully operational and taking referrals.  The coordination unit is revolutionising how we address family violence in Tasmania  to ensure we better protect families experiencing violence and perpetrators are held to account.
Delighted to be involved in the 150th Anniversary celebrations of the town of Margate - my old stomping ground!

Disappointed for the Tasmanian Federal MPs who have lost their seats. They all worked hard and delivered a lot for our State. It certainly was a very fierce and very dishonest scare campaign by Labor on Medicare.    We will continue working hard to keep Tasmania heading in the right direction.
James Hodgman and I have visited all Tasmanian electorates today - supporting a great Tasmanian Liberal Team.   Stick with the plan  it's working. Tasmania is heading in the right direction.

Final stop – Denison.  With dedicated Marcus Allan - Liberal for Denison supporter  Richard  braving the chill. A special shout-out to all booth volunteers today. Great commitment.  Congratulations on a strong  positive campaign  Marcus.   VOTE 1 ALLAN FOR DENISON

Now in my own electorate at beautiful Richmond. With campaign volunteer Matthew and my wingman today  James Hodgman.   Our candidate  Amanda-Sue Markham  is campaigning hard on the western shore of Franklin. VOTE 1 MARKHAM FOR FRANKLIN
I've caught up with the all three amigos. With the hard working Member for Bass Andrew Nikolic AM CSC MP Launceston. VOTE 1 ANDREW NIKOLIC IN BASS
Deloraine with keen Hutchinson supporters. Vote 1 ERIC HUTCHINSON IN LYONS
With Team Hutchinson at Elizabeth Town. VOTE 1 ERIC HUTCHINSON IN LYONS
An early start  and I'm in Devonport with Brett Whiteley and great Liberal member Sally Chandler.
Only the Liberals can ensure a stable majority government that delivers. Don’t risk another Labor-Green-Independent minority government.  Tomorrow vote Liberal Party of Australia in both houses.
With Brooks High School prefects who are part of 'Tomorrow's Leaders Forum' this morning. There has never been a more exciting time to be a Tasmanian!
Great to open 'Tomorrow's Leaders Forum' in Launceston. About 230 students coming together to plan our future.

Curringa Farm is the latest in a string of great tourism ventures to receive funding through the $4.4 million Regional Tourism Infrastructure and Innovation Fund  aimed at creating and supporting tourism infrastructure across Tasmania. This will go a long way to helping us to reach our target of attracting 1.5 million visitors to the state every year by 2020.  Read more here: http://bit.ly/296aAAD

Launching Team Sentinel's prototype combat vehicle in Burnie with Brett Whiteley today. Team Sentinel are bidding for one of the largest Australian Defence Force vehicle replacement contracts in history - the Land 400  phase two contract - worth $3 billion.  Team Sentinel has several competitive advantages and one of its greatest is its Tasmanian content. They have recognised the huge advanced manufacturing capabilities of the Elphinstone Group and the highly skilled workers in Tasmania’s North West.  For Tasmania  this could be the emergence of another competitive strength; defence manufacturing  which is why the State Government is strongly supporting this bid.
AFL legend Robert Dipierdomenico opens Bunnings Warehouse Kingston store. Congratulations to Bunnings management and the 110 staff who will work here.

Touring Tasmanian Cherries by Reid Fruits in Oatlands today with Eric Hutchinson MP. A great family owned Tasmanian success story  Reid Fruits have been growing and exporting produce for over 160 years and are recognised as one of the leading premium cherry brands in many parts of Asia.

At Government House with Tanya Hosch  Joint Campaign Director for Recognise and Her Excellency Professor the Honourable Kate Warner to celebrate the Journey to Recognition Relay in Tasmania.  The country has a once in a generation chance to get this right for all Aboriginal  Torres Strait Islander people and indeed all Australians. Constitutional recognition will mark the first chapter of our history and culture of our nation by the people who first forged it.

As a Lady Gowrie alumni I was delighted to open their superb new children and families centre in Hobart yesterday.  With Chair  Chris McGuire  about to unveil a plaque covered by a beaut painting by Grace  aged 3.

A great honour to speak at the memorial service today for two great Tasmanians – Don and Gwen Hazell  who both passed away recently. Unable to be apart  they are together again. Their extraordinary contribution to Kingborough  and our State  will long be remembered.
Under the Liberals  Tasmania's unemployment rate is down and the economy is growing again. But there's more to be done.  Don't risk another Labor-Green minority Government. On July 2  vote Liberal.

Fantastic to be with Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull and the Federal Liberal team to announce that a re-elected Federal Coalition Government will contribute $150 million towards the relocation and expansion of the University of Tasmania Northern campuses.   We've already backed the plan in our State Budget  which will improve educational opportunities for Tasmanians and transform Launceston and Burnie. Working in partnership with the University of Tasmania and the Federal Government  this commitment will also grow our economy and create many hundreds of building and construction jobs in the north and north west.

It was great to visit KOOEE Snacks - Australia with Guy Barnett today to tour their Legana manufacturing plant which produces premium beef jerky from grass-fed Tasmanian beef  fitting perfectly with Tasmania’s brand which is all about fresh  premium and safe produce.  Emblazoned with images of Tassie icons such as Cradle Mountain and Wineglass Bay  every Kooee product is a little taste of Tasmania and each packet is a mini billboard  selling Tasmania to Australia - and potentially to the world. That's not just great for our economy  local jobs  but also our brand.

Another major milestone today in Tasmania’s successful partnership with Qantas. I was pleased to officially open the newly refurbished Qantas Premium Contact Centre this morning  which coincided with the welcome news that Qantas will be running additional flying capacity in and out of Tasmania during December and January.

It was great to host the Tasmanian Tour of Honour reception at Parliament House today  which recognises the excellence of past and present Australian of the Year Awards recipients.  If you know someone who deserves to be recognised  please consider nominating them today!

A very well attended town hall meeting in Richmond - talking tourism and support for local businesses in our visitor economy. Great to have Luke Martin from the Tourism Industry Council Tasmania and Melinda Anderson from Destination Southern Tasmania along too.
Appalling to hear of the murder of British Labour MP  Jo Cox. Our thoughts and condolences to a family and community so cruelly robbed of a kind  intelligent person.

A re-elected Turnbull Liberal Government will provide $24 million for a fly-over at the intersection known as the Hobart Airport Roundabout. This is a welcome announcement to address a major traffic bottleneck and is supported by a $6 million contribution by the Tasmanian Liberal Government.  This intersection is the major access point to Tasmania’s highest volume passenger airport and links a growing number of industrial and retail subdivisions and the tourist link to the Tasmania’s East Coast – the Great Eastern Drive.

Today in Parliament all parties supported a motion I moved condemning the appalling events in Orlando  Florida.   Forty nine innocent people were killed  and over fifty are wounded. The perpetrator deliberately targeted young LGBTI people.   We extend our thoughts and condolences to all those impacted by this hateful act of terrorism.

Today I delivered a Ministerial Statement in Parliament about the catastrophic floods last week.  The Tasmanian Government stands beside all Tasmanians impacted by these devastating floods – we will help you to recover and to rebuild.
With Tasmania Police Commissioner Darren Hine and former Australian of the Year Rosie Batty at AFL Tasmania's second annual gender equity lunch at Wrest Point today.

With Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull  I've announced a joint disaster assistance package for Tasmanian households  businesses  farms and organisations impacted by the devastating floods is a much needed boost as we move to the recovery phase.  More information can be found here: www.alert.tas.gov.au/floodrecovery

Today I joined the Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull to announce a joint disaster assistance package for Tasmanians impacted by the devastating floods. Assistance is available in 18 council areas for  people whose homes and belongings have been damaged  there’s support for farmers and small businesses and grants for not-for-profit organisations who assist communities to recover.   Information in available at www.alert.tas.gov.au/floodrecovery
Severe damage to the Railton Road in Latrobe vividly  demonstrating the sheer force of the recent floods.

With two of my local Bass Members Peter Gutwein and Michael Ferguson  earlier today I received a briefing from Tasmania SES at the North Region HQ before visiting flood affected areas in Invermay and Newstead.  Thanks to our emergency service crews and volunteers for their excellent response to the crisis as we now shift to the recovery process.

Flood Assistance for Tasmanians in Need        The Tasmanian Government is moving to offer immediate assistance to those who have lost homes and belongings in the worst floods this State has seen in 40 years. The Government will make available emergency aid of up to $750 a family – $200 per adult and $100 per child – for Tasmanians in need through Service Tasmania. This will assist with providing clothing  food  transport  shelter and personal items. We are also examining other support measures and we have officers on the ground supporting with stock management and doing Rapid Impact Assessments where possible.  We remind people in life-threatening situations to call 000 and for those that require non-urgent flood-related assistance to call the SES on 132 500. Financial assistance will be made available through Service Tasmania  but if you're unable to attend a location  please call 1300 13 55 13.  Our thoughts and prayers are with the families and friends of the Tasmanians currently missing.

With significant rainfall affecting many parts of the state today  please assist Tasmania Police  Tasmania SES and our emergency services by obeying instructions and driving safely on our roads.  Thankyou to staff and volunteers for assisting with operations and keeping Tasmanians safe.

Today's joint agreement between the Tasmanian Government  AFL  TT-Line  and the North Melbourne Football Club is not just great news for footy fans  but a great deal for Tasmania.  The agreement announced today will see better talent pathways  enhanced support for Women's Football and three NMFC rostered games played in Hobart per year between 2017 and 2021.  Read more here: http://bit.ly/20WKMJy

The Tasmanian Government's Plan to reduce Elective Surgery waiting lists is working. As at the end of April 2016  the Elective Surgery Waiting List has reduced to its lowest point in almost three years.  There is much more work to be done to support a better health system for Tasmania  but we are proud that our Plan is delivering better health outcomes for Tasmanians.

The #TasBudget provides an additional $60 million in funding towards the Government's Affordable Housing Strategy and Action Plan  which will deliver around 900 new homes and provide support programs to house up to 1600 vulnerable Tasmanian families by 2019.  Read more here: http://bit.ly/1VoYW6M

The 2016/17 #TasBudget includes a total investment of $656 million in road and bridge improvements for the State  funded jointly by the State and Federal Governments. These projects will support jobs in the civil construction sector and address vital infrastructure needs to support our growing economy.  Read more here: http://bit.ly/1TGXc43

The #TasBudget provides a total of $90 million for the Northern Cities Major Development Initiative to support infrastructure projects in Launceston's University of Tasmania relocation to Inveresk  Devonport's Living City project and the Burnie UTAS campus.  These developments will bring much needed investment in these three cities and also generate ongoing employment opportunities for Tasmanians.

The #TasBudget includes $515 million in funding for Frontline Health infrastructure  including the Royal Hobart Hospital Redevelopment  the upgrade of the Children’s Ward 4K at the Launceston General Hospital and more upgrades to existing hospital and health centres across Tasmania.

The #TasBudget puts Tasmania back on track  reinvesting in core essential services while balancing the books to a surplus for the first time in seven years.  But don't just take our word for it - here's what others are saying about this year's Budget  and you can read more here: http://bit.ly/1TFYbXH

The #TasBudget will deliver a fleet of 100 brand new Metro Tasmania buses through a $31 million initiative - the single biggest investment in public transport in Tasmania’s history. Our Government is committed to providing a sustainable public transport system for Tasmanians. We strongly encourage Tasmanian business to bid to build and fit-out these new buses.  Read more here: http://bit.ly/1WYu3rB

Great to meet Charles Meunier and his parents Emma and Keith  with Hawthorn Football Club CEO Stuart Fox.   Charles  from Melbourne  was recently selected as a NAB AFL Auskicker of the Year nominee. When interviewed on national TV  he said his dream was to come to Tasmania. So  Tourism Northern Tasmania has arranged for Charles and his parents to come down watch the Hawks match and spend a few days in Launceston. Charles is Tasmania's latest ambassador!

The $24 million Tasmanian jobs and investment fund launched yesterday is a great demonstration of State and Federal Governments working together. It is also evidence of very high levels of business confidence  with many Tasmanian businesses subscribing to the program. The 56 projects around the state are expected to generate 774 new jobs and over $92 million in investment. See the full list of the projects that will be supported here.

The Tasmanian Government's economic plan focuses on capitalising on our competitive strengths  which includes one of our greatest assets - our brand  and there's never been a better time to promote our state and our reputation to the world.  This is why the upcoming State Budget will include a $650 000 investment to amp up our brand. It’s about capturing what Tasmania is today  and having a single story for us all to tell to promote our island - our people  place and produce  which we know are the best in the world.

While the recent rains might have had an adverse effect on some social plans  they've been a most welcome event for our Hydro dams  which have increased by over 3% in the last week. While there's still a lot of work to be done to rebuild our dam levels  our Energy Supply Plan is ensuring that Tasmanians can continue to reliably meet their power needs.

As we enter National Volunteer Week  a big congratulations to the finalists of the inaugural Tasmanian Volunteer Awards ceremony held at Government House today - and especially to Peter Martin from Sheffield  who was recognised as Volunteer of the Year.   I would again like to congratulate all winners and finalists  and thank the many volunteers within our community who selflessly dedicate their time to make our state an even better place.

Tasmanians have a huge amount at stake in this election.   The Coalition Government has delivered significantly for Tasmania over the past three years  including through increased freight support to boost our exports; Free Trade Agreements have opened up new markets for Tasmanian business; irrigation infrastructure to grow our agricultural sector; investments in the Midland Highway and at the Hobart airport; and to cement our position as the Antarctic gateway.  Under Malcolm Turnbull  the Coalition also has plan for a strong new economy  to deliver more jobs and opportunities for Australians. In contrast  Mr Shorten has no plan other than to spend more  and tax more. That would cost jobs and hurt Tasmania's economy - especially our small businesses.  'Like' the Tasmanian Liberals Facebook page for updates throughout the 2016 Federal election campaign.
74th Anniversary of the Battle of the Coral Sea  which is said to have saved Australia.
Great to meet Rural Youth committee members Ricky Edson  Kate Coad  Emma Reyner  Bree House and Dayna Brown: the hardworking team behind Agfest. One of Tasmania's great events!

Meeting one of our Biosecurity team  Locky  at AGFEST  and the launch of a new guide to farming safely in Tasmania will help to improve the workplace health and safety on farms across Tasmania.  The Farming Safely in Tasmania Guide and USB is part of the Government’s $435 000 Safe Farming Tasmania Program aimed at reducing accidents and illness on Tasmanian farms.  We have already made significant gains through this program over the past year including responding to almost 100 requests for advice  31 on-farm consultations  33 presentations to students and farm managers and participation in 14 trade shows and conferences.

Education Minister Jeremy Rockliff spoke to students from South Hobart Primary School about the upcoming improvements being made to their school  along with eight other Tasmanian schools  following our $28 million construction boom announcement today.  These projects will ensure Tasmanian students have access to contemporary and flexible learning facilities where they have the greatest opportunity to explore their passions and discover a path to their future career. Read more here: http://bit.ly/1SZUvN1

On air with David Wood on ultra106.5 FM after launching the Salvation Army #RedShieldAppeal with a $30 000 donation.  The upcoming State Budget will also include $300 million worth of concessions to support Tasmanians  including assistance for Public Housing Rent Assistance  Metro Tasmania concessions  electricity rebates and local Government rates.

The Federal Budget unveiled yesterday is great news for over 36 000 Tasmanian small businesses - 94% of which will receive tax relief to assist in growing their businesses and hiring more employees. Tasmania’s economy is growing at its fastest rate in six years  and several new Budget initiatives will further support the 100 000 Tasmanians employed in the small business sector and create more jobs across the state.  Read more about the measures included to strengthen the economy here: http://budget.gov.au/

Great to be out with Elise Archer MP to launch the Salvation Army Red Shield Appeal in Hobart today. The Tasmanian Government is proud to kick-start the Salvatian Army's major annual fundraiser with a $30 000 donation to support its social and community services provided by 20 Tasmanian centres. Please get behind their campaign here: https://salvos.org.au/donate/make-a-donation/donate-online/?appeal=rsa2016

The Tasmanian Government says thanks to our brave firefighters. The 2015-16 fire season was an extremely challenging one for the state  and we owe our hardworking professional and volunteer firefighters a debt of gratitude for keeping our communities safe. Today we held a community BBQ lunch in Burnie to say thanks.   The government welcomes the Australasian Fire and Emergency Services Authorities Council (AFAC) report into our firefighting efforts through the past summer. The AFAC report says: "Overall  we think that the way in which the fires were managed is a tribute to the Tasmanian fire agencies  their leadership and all personnel involved in this incident.

On the NW Coast today with Minister Rene Hidding to say thanks to all those involved in the fire fighting effort over the summer. Two months  300 fires  3100 brave Tasmanian  interstate and NZ firey's!

It's fantastic to join Foreign Minister Julie Bishop MP in welcoming around 80 Canberra-based heads of foreign diplomatic missions to Tasmania. Over three days  the diplomatic corps will be exposed to some of the best Tasmanian businesses  tourism and cultural experiences our state has to offer  so they can better inform their home countries of the immense investment and trade opportunities available here.

On this day  20 years ago  Tasmania and Australia changed forever. Today and forever  we remember the 35 people who lost their lives at Port Arthur  and pray for their families and loved ones. Our thoughts are with those who were injured  23 people whose lives were so dreadfully affected.  As we reflect on today’s anniversary  each of us will have our own memories. We will experience different emotions  and old wounds may open  while for others those wounds may have never healed. But as we look back on our past  I trust we can all find some hope. From one of our state’s darkest chapters  we have become a stronger and safer place.

Today we commemorate a defining chapter in our country’s story. We remember the first ANZACs  and all Australians who have served and died in all wars  conflicts and peacekeeping operations since. We pay gratitude for their sacrifices and actions that have defined and protected what it means to be Australian.  Lest we forget.
ANZAC Day Dawn Service at Kingston Beach. A spectacular setting for a sacred occasion. Lest we forget.

Opening the Tasmanian Motocross Championships today at Cambridge Moto.   Congratulations to Greg Cassimaty and team on developing the course to host the event. And also providing a venue for kids to safely ride their bikes at  and off suburban streets.

Today  the Tasmanian Liberal Government has announced that Specialist Medical Practitioners will be able to prescribe medical cannabis to Tasmanians with serious or chronic illnesses under the Controlled Access Scheme (CAS) from no later than 2017. The scheme will allow access to medical cannabis products grown lawfully under Commonwealth licenses  when they come onto the market.  The Department of Health and Human Services is currently developing the full details of the Controlled Access Scheme  with guidelines to be publicly released later this year.  Read more here: http://bit.ly/1Sirm0d

Fantastic to be on Bruny Island today with Federal Tourism Minister Richard Colbeck  Amanda-Sue Markham - Liberal for Franklin and my colleagues Jacquie Petrusma MP and Nic Street MP to announce two new tourism ventures to improve the Island for visitors and locals.  Pennicott Wilderness Journeys will develop a multipurpose tourism centre  which includes a restaurant  retail space and visitor amenities  and Bruny Island Cheese Co. is set to expand their cellar door tasting facilities and indoor seating area to allow it to better cater for tour group bookings.  This is yet another example of how working cooperatively and constructively with the Liberal Government in Canberra provides better outcomes for Tasmania.
Heading to Bruny Island today. The massive boost in Island tourism a major focus.

The international cricket spotlight will be shining on Tasmania when South Africa takes on Australia at Blundstone Arena for the very first time this November.  The 2016-17 Men’s International Cricket Schedule is not only welcome news for fans  but for our state as a whole and gives Tasmanians a chance to watch the world’s best cricket in our own backyard.  I encourage all Tasmanians to take the opportunity later this year to support Australia and enjoy a great sporting battle.

The Tasmanian Government has today endorsed a report from Infrastructure Tasmania to seek funding from the Federal Government for a new Bridgewater Bridge.  The new four-lane bridge will enable pedestrian and cyclist facilities  while also allowing more efficient vehicle travel on the Midland Highway and reducing the burdens of current height  mass and width restrictions. It will be the single most important transport infrastructure project in the state since the Tasman Bridge was built in the 1960s.  Funding for the bridge will be sought through the next five-year round of the Federal Government’s Infrastructure Investment Program. If successful  work on the project is anticipated to start in 2019-20.

Launching in September  the first Australian Antarctic Festival will become a fantastic new addition to Tasmania’s festival line up.   Hobart has served as the gateway to the Antarctic for well over a century  with scientists and research vessels refuelling  restocking and recouping before heading further south - so it's appropriate that the festival celebrates this history and our present day bond.  The Tasmanian Liberal Government is proud to support the festival through Events Tasmania  which will help draw even more visitors to our state this September.
Today we met with the State Oceanic Administration of China in Beijing to discuss progress on our partnership agreement signed last year to further  cooperation in Antarctic affairs.

Today an agreement was struck  between Shandong Chambroad and TasTAFE to work on developing a major new hospitality training school in Tasmania.    Chambroad will also partner with Hunter Developments on a proposal for a new $45 million 4 to 5 star boutique hotel development as part of the Clarance City Council's EOI process for Kangaroo Bay.
Important deals struck today including by UTas  Bellamys and Mt Wellington Honey to strengthen business with China  and support Tasmanian industry and jobs.
Australia Week in China shifts to a purely Tasmanian focus at a Savour Tasmania reception tonight - bringing together businesses who invest in our state.

Speaking at the Australia-China Week agribusiness investment seminar. Promoting one of our great competitive strengths  in our largest market  through vast opportunities opened up through the Free Trade Agreement.

Today I lead an 'Australia Week in China' delegation visit to Haibawang Food Logistics Park  in Chengdu  Sichuan Province.   One of the largest and newest food distribution centres in west China  it stores over 250 000 tonnes of seafood a day! - including an increasing amount from Australia.   A number of our agribusinesses attended  including Trigonia Seafoods and See3 from Tasmania.
An exhibition at Fujian Museum - to celebrate the 35th anniversary of our sister-state relationship - featuring exceptional Tasmanian and Chinese artists.

Tasmania Week in China hits the premium Yonghui Superstore - featuring fine Tasmanian products like honey  abalone  wine and baby formula!  Yonghui Superstore is a massive market for fine Tassie products. The rapid increase in our exports to China is supporting more jobs and investment in Tasmanian businesses.

Signing of a new agreement with Fujian Provincial Tourism Bureau and the Tasmanian Government to promote Tasmania and Fujian as traveller destinations  exchange industry information and work experience programs. We are building our partnership to maintain the massive growth in tourists coming to our state - which supports  local Tasmanian businesses and jobs.

A busy couple of days in Singapore progressing important opportunities in trade and investment  tourism and education.   Also an important meeting with the owners of Basslink - where I received assurances the repair work is a priority.    The University of Tasmania Law School also held an event for alumni - to expand our connections abroad and promote Tasmania as a great place to study.

Today  the Government introduced the Taxi and Hire Vehicle Industries Amendment Bill to Parliament which would will allow a person to operate a vehicle as a ride-sourcing service. This will support consumer choice  while providing appropriate protections. In contrast  the Labor Party opposed our Bill.

The economic spotlight was on our state today! In an historic first  Reserve Bank Governor Glenn Stevens and the Reserve Bank board met in Hobart. It’s a great chance for the RBA to see our strengthening economy.

We are taking action to ensure patients get the care they need sooner in emergency departments at the Royal Hobart and Launceston General Hospitals.  Our Patients First plan will deal with a spike in demand in emergency  and is in addition to our One Health System reforms to deliver a better health system.

As a result of the Tasmanian Government's strong advocacy at today's COAG meeting  the State's health system has been allocated an additional $54 million in Commonwealth funding from 2017-2020. In addition  the proposal to allow states to individually levy income tax  which would have hurt Tasmania  will not proceed.   Watch my comments to media following the conclusion of the COAG meeting below.
In Canberra to protect Tasmania from an income tax proposal that would disadvantage our state  and to fight for more health and education funding.

Yesterday's confirmation from Basslink that the thumb-sized cable fault has now been identified and removed is good news and a significant positive development. It has also been confirmed that both the southern and northern ends of the cable are completely fault-free.  With Basslink advising Government of a mid-June return to service date  this means a significant amount of uncertainty around the repair of the cable has been removed.   Through our Energy Supply Plan  the Government is continuing to do everything necessary to maintain energy security.The advice we continue to receive is that with all of the contingencies provided by our Plan  we can continue to meet Tasmanian's energy requirements.  Read more here: http://bit.ly/1Y09reR
Recently refreshing my understanding of proper resuscitation techniques. It's well worth doing this when possible - it could save a life.

Great to officially open The Zone - a cool  custom designed space that allows young adults with disability to meet up with friends and have fun.  The opening of the Zone coincides with the 100 day countdown until the commencement of transition to the full roll out of the National Disability Insurance Scheme (NDIS).  The Liberal Government is proud to deliver on its commitment to implement the full NDIS for the people of Tasmania  which is revolutionising the delivery of services to people living with disability.  Congratulations and thanks to Liviende Veranto for their continued commitment to providing important services for people with disability - and on establishing The Zone.

Great to host an event in celebration of Harmony Day_AU today  and particularly enjoyed a classical South Indian musical performance by Santhanan and Sakthi.  Now in its sixteenth year  Harmony Day observes the cultural  economic and social contributions of our multicultural community. To help celebrate this multicultural community  my Government has provided funding to help facilitate activities around Harmony Day across the State during Tasmania’s inaugural Harmony Week  celebrated from 14-21 March.
Harmony Week celebrations kicking off in Launceston  with a very simple but powerful message - “everyone belongs!”
A beautiful morning for the Launceston & Henley Regatta.

Congratulations to the JAC Group on a superb redevelopment of the iconic Penny Royal. Another first class attraction for Tasmania's tourism industry.   They’ve not only given a past tourism icon a new lease on life  but they’ve supported 100 jobs during construction and will create up to 100 ongoing jobs once the site is fully operational.  What the JAC Group has created is unlike anything else in Tasmania; combining adventure  history and gourmet produce across a five hectare property  with something for everyone!

Dropping by Lauderdale Primary School today with Nic Street  Jacquie Petrusma MP  Jonathon Duniam - Liberal Senate candidate and Amanda-Sue Markham - Liberal for Franklin to celebrate the school's 50th birthday!  We had a wonderful tour around the school provided by some excellent student tour guides. Thanks to students and staff for an enjoyable time with you on this very special occasion.

Today we released our comprehensive blueprint for the future of gaming in Tasmania. We understand this is a very important issue and we are determined not to repeat the mistakes of past Governments - where secret deals were signed and presented to the Tasmanian people without proper consultation and transparency. Key points of our Plan include:  ✔ 150 less pokie machines ✔ Pokie licence to go to the market  for the first time ✔ Potential MONA high-roller casino ✔ Full community consultation  See here for more detail: http://bit.ly/1nQ3CUX

In Parliament yesterday  I made comments which are entirely unacceptable  deeply offensive and for which there is no excuse.  My unconditional apology also extends to the people of Tasmania who have been let down.  I will make every effort to right the wrongs I have caused by my comments.

Today marks two years since our election  and Tasmania is now headed in the right direction.  As you can see from the 2014 campaign video below  while we haven’t been perfect  and there’s a lot more work to do  we’ve been consistent in delivering what we promised before the election.  A snapshot of our achievements can be found here http://bit.ly/Snapshot16 and our full AGENDA 2016 document here: http://bit.ly/Agenda_2016

The Tasmanian Government is absolutely committed to improving educational outcomes by making structural change  targeted investment and prioritising students with greatest need.  Today we have released a draft modern Education Act - the result an 18 month review and extensive community consultation around the state.  Our proposed changes include: - lowering the compulsory minimum starting age (for prep) by six months  to four years and six months  - increasing the leaving requirements to completion of Year 12  a Certificate III  or reaching 18-years of age.  As it stands Tasmanian students can leave school with as much as two years less education than students interstate.   And  almost half of our children miss out on high quality learning at a young age because not every family can afford child care or private education.   We want every Tasmanian to have equal access to a quality education for longer.
Delighted to officially open the Hobart Chiropractic and Multidisciplinary Centre. Congratulations to Dr Stephen Crean and team. High quality allied health services under one roof.

Our young people are our greatest asset  and improving educational outcomes is critically important for their future prosperity and the prosperity of our state.  Tasmania currently has the oldest minimum school starting age  and the result of this is that our students can legally leave school earlier than others around the country. We can’t expect to be better by doing less.  Changing the starting age will bring us into line with the rest of Australia  and narrow the gap that currently results in many Tasmanians walking out of school with as much as two years less education than their interstate counterparts.

The Skal Australia National Assembly is open. Tourism and travel leaders from across the globe are meeting in Tasmania – the nation's top destination.   It's fitting they're meeting here; our Hobart Club was recently awarded international club of the year  joining many Tasmanian businesses and organisations that are being recognised as the best in the world.
Opening the 2016 Swimming Tasmania Championships with Speaker Elise Archer MP  Over 400 participants  including many from interstate competing. Good luck to all!

Our long-term Plan for a Brighter Future is moving to its next phase.  Year one was about stemming the bleeding in our economy and our budget. Year two was about consolidating the gains and building the momentum. Year three  this year  is about investing the dividends of those gains into the core  essential services  and future-proofing our State.  Download your personal copy of AGENDA 2016 - the Tasmanian Government's practical plan for the next 12 months here: http://bit.ly/Agenda_2016

During my State of the State speech in Parliament today  I released our plan for the year ahead - AGENDA 2016.  AGENDA 2016 lays out our practical work plan for the year  as we sharpen our focus on investing in essential services such as health  education  and protecting the vulnerable  and continue to work to ensure Tasmania is well placed to address long-term challenges.  Download your own copy of the document here: http://bit.ly/Agenda_2016

Showcasing Tasmanian business  tourism  culture and investment opportunities with 83 Ambassadors and High Commissioners as part of the Diplomatic Corps visit.  We visited the culturally iconic MONA  met with innovative Tasmanian manufacturing businesses including INCAT and Liferaft Systems; and attended a Tasmanian trade fair featuring high quality fresh local produce. We also spent time at the Australian Antarctic Division  where we heard about Tasmania's important role as a gateway to Antarctica and our research and technological capabilities.

Today we commemorate the 20th anniversary of the Port Arthur massacre which took the lives of 35 people & injured 23 others.   We remember the victims  their families and loved ones  and all those affected by this tragedy.

In Tasmania to sign a contract for a new Antarctic icebreaker as part of the Australian Antarctic Strategy & 20 Year Action Plan.   The Turnbull Government supports world-class science & innovation through the Australian Antarctic program providing opportunities  jobs and growth for Tasmania as the premier Gateway to East Antarctica.

Yesterday Assistant Minister for Defence Michael McCormack and I announced the redevelopment of Seaward Village in the suburb of Swanbourne in my electorate.   The announcement of an upgrade of the residences is a fantastic outcome for SAS families & local residents.

Today we honour and remember the ANZACS and pay tribute to all members of the Australian Defence Force.  I attended the Dawn Service at Kings Park and lay wreaths at services at Shenton Park  Subiaco and Mosman Park.   Lest we forget.

Barnaby Joyce Member for New England and I were delighted to announce yesterday that Australia will contribute to the Global Crop Diversity Trust to safeguard the world’s crops and strengthen global food security.  Our contribution is a great example of how the government is helping Australian farmers and how Australian farmers are helping to feed the world.🌾🌽  http://foreignminister.gov.au/releases/Pages/2016/jb_mr_160420a.aspx

Last time I checked  most of the votes in this election have not been cast  let alone counted. But here was Mr Turnbull smugly deciding he’s already won:  “We will win on July 2nd … Australians will return us to Government.”  Early voting only started on Tuesday  yet by that night Mr Turnbull had already claimed victory.  That kind of arrogance comes from being seriously out of touch. It is typical of the Liberals' 'born to rule' mentality.  The people who will decide the future of this country are 16 million Australians  not Mr Turnbull.  Australians who care about Medicare. About hospitals. About schools. About the NBN. Anyone who has attended one of the nineteen town halls I’ve held across the country will be able to tell you that I’m not afraid of meeting people from all walks of life.   These are not stage managed and the forums are open to all.  I don't expect that every answer I'll give will be the exact answer that everyone wants to hear.   But people are making assessments about what is the character of the leader or the person who wishes to lead a government.   I'm prepared to demonstrate to people that I'll work hard  that I'll answer their questions honestly.  When I meet people like Lindsay in Grovedale who has had to wait two and a half years to have knee reconstruction  I know that this country can and must do better than that.  When I meet young people who fear they will be permanently locked out of the housing market because the Federal Government gives more taxpayer subsidies to property speculators buying their tenth property than to young people trying to buy their first home  I know that this country can and must do better than that.  When I meet parents concerned about whether their kids will be able to afford TAFE or university and whether decent jobs will be available to them  I know that our country is crying out for the kind of political leadership that puts their interests first.  I am determined to change the way we do politics in Australia  I want people and their voices to be at the centre of political debate in this country.

Labor deplores the brutal acts of terror in #Brussels that have left at least 34 people dead and more than 200 injured.   Our thoughts are with all those affected by this terrible tragedy.     In the face of this abhorrent violence  Australians stand shoulder to shoulder with our Belgian friends.   Along with the international community  we must continue to stand up against terror  hatred  and extremism  wherever it exists. Good morning Aspendale.

SKY RAIL RULED OUT FOR FRANKSTON LINE  Today the Victorian State Minister for Transport  the Hon. Jacinta Allan MP made it absolutely clear that there will be no ‘Sky Rail’ on the Frankston Train Line and that the Victorian Government will not be building one.  Eleven level crossings are being removed on the Frankston line. Three are already being removed with rail under road and the remaining eight crossings are spaced out along the rail corridor.   Within these eight level crossings to be removed there are a number of level crossings that will be left in place.   This rules out an extended elevated line  as will be built on the Dandenong train line  and the Victorian Government will not be building one.   This confirmation by the Victorian Government has exposed the Liberal Party’s shameful lies to our community. The Liberals had hoped that they could use the community consultation period of the Level Crossing Removal Authority to spread misinformation and scare local residents by claiming on a recent flyer that the State Government had a plan for a ‘four-storey sky rail near you’. There was never such a plan.  The State Government’s confirmation that there will be no Sky Rail on the Frankston Line  and that there were never any plans for one  has exposed the Liberals’ misinformation campaign for what it is  petty partisan lies by a desperate and deceitful Liberal Party.  The State Government has made it absolutely clear. There will be no Sky Rail on the Frankston Line and there was never any plan for one.  You can read the State Government’s media release at: http://www.premier.vic.gov.au/frankston-level-crossing-lies-a-desperate-political-stunt/

Australia's 11.7 million taxpayers pay an average of $310 per year to pay for negative gearing tax concessions.  Negative gearing tax concessions cost over $3.6 billion last year   about as much as the government spent on assistance to jobseekers and vocational training  and twice what it spent on assistance to indigenous Australians. These tax concessions are shutting Australians out of the property market  with investors routinely outbidding prospective buyers  driving up the cost of housing.  Only Labor has a plan to end negative gearing tax concessions for investors  with exemptions for new constructions and no change to existing negatively geared properties.  Supported by economists  our policy is good for Australia and good for prospective homebuyers  who shouldn't have to bid against an investor buying their sixth or seventh investment property.

Liberal National MP George Christensen doesn't believe in the findings of climate scientists. Or of marine scientists. He'd rather listen to the conspiracy theories of talkback hosts and interest groups.   With members like this  it's not a surprise when the Liberal Party cut jobs and funding from the CSIRO - but it's still devastating.  Labor takes science seriously. We listen to scientists  because they know what they're talking about. If you needed legal advice  you wouldn't ask your local bus driver  you'd go to a lawyer or legal aid centre. If you needed scientific advice  you wouldn't go to a fossil fuel lobbyist  you'd see a scientist. But many members of the Liberal Party are rejecting the advice of scientists for that of lobbyists and fringe interest groups  and it's damaging Australia's reputation as a leading place for science and research.  You just can't trust the Liberals to take science seriously.
